—My question is to the Minister for Social Security. What number of Social Security clients came forward to declare overpayments during the period of the recently concluded amnesty? On that basis, does the Government expect the Budget savings estimate of $55m attributable to the amnesty to be met by the end of the financial year? How many amnesty application forms did the Department of Social Security mail out during the six-week period? Did the mail-out include persons whose names appeared on suspected overpayments facility listings? Were some of these persons suspected of having received overpayments in circumstances which would not have entitled them to protection under the amnesty arrangements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston may be aware that I got back from overseas this morning. I arrived at Parliament only 45 minutes before Question Time, so I have not had time to get across everything that has happened in the last two weeks. My understanding is, however, that the number of people who came forward on the amnesty is around 20,000. I will get an accurate figure for the honourable senator, if not today, then certainly tomorrow. I understand that the numbers are fairly close to the numbers that we expected to come in in the amnesty. However, it would appear that the amounts that we look like recovering are not as high as we had estimated. I will not be able to tell whether or not the figure will come in substantially lower than the Budget figure until we make an estimate of how many people simply cancel their benefits from the Department of Social Security on the basis of the publicity associated with the amnesty, and there was some factoring in of a figure for that in the Budget.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not know exactly how long it will take for me to get those final figures, but if Senator Alston wants an estimate-that is all I can give and it has to be fairly rough given, as I said, that I have literally only just got off the plane-I think the figure is likely to be close to 40 million rather than to 55 million. The honourable senator will have to give me some leeway on that matter as I will not be certain for a few more days.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. There was a second part to the question. I presume that the Minister will in due course provide an answer to that, given that he does not seem to have had fax facilities available to him where he might have been recently. I hope that, at the same time that he provides the additional information, he will be prepared to indicate the basis on which the original estimate was made and, therefore, the reasons why the actual figure is below that estimate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer to the flight delays at Canberra Airport last night due, I believe, to a lack of runway lights. Can the Minister please explain what damage was caused by the fire at Canberra Airport last night? What arrangements have been put in place to overcome any problems caused by the fire?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Batteries, actually. There was a fire at 5.30 p.m. last night in the building on the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) side of the Canberra Airport, which houses the switchboard equipment for operating the runway, taxiway and visual approach slope indicator system lights at the airport. The damage was extensive. The cause of the fire at the moment is unknown. I am told that I will have a report later on this afternoon on the full extent of the damage but, as already reported to me, the fire damage is extensive.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Maguire has alluded to the extinguishing of the runway lights and the taxiway lights. The RAAF managed to install last night, I must say very rapidly, an emergency system of lighting powered by batteries at the airport. That system is still being used. I am assured by the airport operators that that system will be quite safely and effectively used, but I will be able to give a fuller report on when full services will be restored through the switchboard at a later stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Social Security explain the nexus between a medical impairment and work force incapacity which currently determines eligibility for the invalid pension? Is it a fact that persons with as little as a 15 per cent medical impairment have been held to have an 85 per cent incapacity for work?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The difference between impairment and incapacity has been at the heart of the debate on invalid pensions over many years. What has to be compared is the level of medical dysfunction with the way that that medical impairment will affect a person's capacity to work. Obviously, it is arbitrary by nature and that is why, I think, we are always going to have difficulties and disagreements about it.

ANSWER.PARA: The changes in the Budget this year moved more to the medical impairment than was the case in the past. In the calculations for incapacity we had a range of factors-such as age and even language-that had been taken into account, in my view, too much. We have moved to take the calculation away from that and look much more at levels of medical impairment. It is possible that, in the past, 15 per cent levels of medical impairment have led to calculations of 85 per cent incapacity-that has occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question in the light of that response. Is the invalid pension to be replaced by a disability support pension because the Government is not satisfied with the current basis for entitlement and, if so, why will the new scheme not come into operation for another 12 months, when Professor Bettina Cass identified these problems more than two years ago?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, we are going to have a new payment to replace the invalid pension. We have had reviews on this question going back to 1984. I think it was a very significant reform that we announced in the Budget. At the heart of it was our belief that some of those persons going on invalid payments can be streamed into an active stream where rehabilitation and training can be sought, and where some employment prospects will exist. Given that, we have to make sure that the numbers of rehabilitation places and training places are available and also that the system is explained to those who will be affected by it.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not believe we should approach major reforms of that kind by announcing that they will start very soon. We have taken the time to ensure that there will be places available in rehabilitation and training, and to make the community aware of this very fundamental change-one which, I am sure, most people in the community will support and certainly one that has been supported by organisations for the disabled.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Is the Minister aware of the findings of Hobart-based consulting engineer, Mr Andrew Boon, that proposed changes to Australia's maritime radio safety network may derive from incorrect engineering data and may, therefore, represent additional risks to professional fishers and small boat owners in Tasmanian waters? Has the Minister read a report in the Hobart Mercury of 26 September 1990 in which the chief of Tasmania's police search and rescue unit, Inspector Maurice Massie, suggested that the proportion of radio calls from Tasmanian waters which can be quickly and easily received by authorities will drop from over 90 per cent to 70 per cent if the closure of Hobart Radio proceeds? Can the Minister give an assurance, firstly, that the closure of Hobart Radio will be reviewed in the light of these findings and, secondly, that the performance of any new radio safety arrangements will at least equal those of the existing network?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can certainly give Senator Coates an assurance that, providing boat owners are responsible enough to re-equip their craft with equipment capable of using the new state-of-the-art technology which the Federal Government has now in place rather than the obsolescent technology that was formerly employed by OTC Ltd, those services will certainly be at least the equivalent of the current radio services being provided.

ANSWER.PARA: The question of the withdrawal of Commonwealth support for OTC was a matter for debate at a meeting of State and Federal Transport Ministers-the Australian Transport Advisory Council-some several meetings ago. There was agreement from all State Ministers, including the New South Wales Transport Minister but not the Minister for Transport in Tasmania, about the basis on which the Commonwealth made that decision. Quite simply, the Commonwealth has established state-of-the-art technology for maritime search and rescue. That is administered through a ground station at Alice Springs in the Northern Territory which transmits by landline to the Sea Safety Centre in Canberra and operates both an effective system of high frequency radio communication and EPIRBs-the emergency position indicating radio beacons.

Some small fisheries, particularly in Tasmania, are affected to some degree by the removal of local radio systems because these fisheries, in particular the lobster fishery in Tasmania, operate very close to shore-in fact under cliffs in some cases-and were not even properly serviced by OTC radio.

I am aware of the report that Senator Coates has referred to. At the moment it is being technically assessed by officers of my Department. I have not had an opportunity yet, because that assessment has only just begun, to look at it, but I will certainly be addressing that report. I am happy to provide Senator Coates or indeed the Senate with a more detailed response after I have read it.

But the basis of the Federal Government's position quite simply is that we have installed state-of-the-art technology which fully meets all of the obligations of the Federal Government under the international treaties that provide for sea safety, search and rescue. That system is currently costing the Commonwealth $11m a year to run and the Commonwealth simply took the view-and I think correctly-that it was not reasonable to expect the Commonwealth to fully fund a brand new state-of-the-art system at $11m a year while at the same time maintaining the obsolete system that it replaces, which, in the case of Tasmania alone, costs half a million dollars a year. However, having said that, I will be happy to address the concerns raised in this report after I have had an opportunity to examine it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is the Minister aware of the declining employment opportunities in the sawmilling industries of south-eastern New South Wales and east Gippsland in Victoria which are due to rapidly increasing use of pine timber for construction purposes and the increasing mechanisation in the sawmilling industry? In view of these trends, does the Government intend to assist in the development of alternative industries to generate employment in these areas and to establish hardwood plantations to meet any remaining future demands for hardwood timber, financing such initiatives in part out of higher licence fees and levies on export woodchips from non-National Estate forests? Does the Minister agree that this is a more sensible strategy than the Government's present short-sighted course of destroying old growth National Estate forests which in any case will not safeguard jobs in the longer term?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The pros- pects for employment in the timber industry have been at the centre of this debate for a long time. The Commonwealth has over the past few years attempted, in Tasmania, Victoria and New South Wales, to maximise those employment opportunities while still hopefully protecting as much as we can of our old growth forest. Senator Powell attributes as a reason for the decline of employment in sawmills a rapid increase in the use of pines in the building industry. That is certainly occurring. I would have thought that the improvements in technology in the last few years might have had an effect almost as great as the use of pines in the building industry on that employment in the sawmills. I am not sure which would be greater, but certainly they are both significant reasons for that decline in employment. If one goes back to the agreement with Tasmania in 1988, one will see that the Commonwealth was involved in looking at hardwood plantations then.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not certain as to the exact state of negotiations in Gippsland now. But my understanding is that a report has been given to the Victorian Government which the Commonwealth has yet to discuss with it. Obviously, in respect of the south-eastern forests of New South Wales, there has been an announcement of some note in the last 24 hours. My understanding is that hardwood plantations will be considered there again. I will have to find out from Mrs Kelly exactly where that discussion on hardwood plantations is up to.

As I think everyone in the Government has acknowledged over the past few years, hardwood plantations are certainly one of the answers that the industry will have to look to if it wants to have a secure future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for his answer, as far as it goes. But I ask him to address what was the essence of the third part of the question, that is, does he not agree that all that destruction of old growth forests in the National Estate can do, if it goes ahead, is safeguard jobs in the very short term? Does he not agree that it would be a far better strategy to finance initiatives in the shorter term by higher licence fees and levies on export woodchips which are currently going out of those areas from non-National Estate forests?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —First off, National Estate listing has never meant that exploitation of the area was forbidden under all or any circumstances. I might say that that was never even part of the origins of the National Estate, which, of course, had its foundations in Whitlam's term of government. It was always the case that we were recognising special areas of Australia. But, equally, it was always the case that this was being done on the basis of whether or not there were prudent and feasible alternatives for development. That is a principle that has applied ever since that legislation came into the Parliament. So my first point is that exploitation of old growth forests in the National Estate has never been prevented by the legislation that set up the National Estate in the first place.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of their destruction being a short term job saving exercise, I am not certain whether that is right. It is the case that the industry would claim that with proper-

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you think you should be certain before you destroy old growth forests?

—I will answer. I am not attempting to duck any part of it. Just give me a chance. I must admit that I am not thinking at 100 miles an hour today. I do not think one can be certain that that is the case. The industry will certainly claim that in its management of old growth forests in the first place, and then what replaces them, proper sustainable forestry will mean that jobs will not be lost and, theoretically, could increase if forests are exploited properly. That is a claim that industry has made for ever. Being certain about its truth, of course, is a matter of defining what is sustainable logging. I have always personally had a difficulty in coming to grips with a definition because it has changed so much over time. But on the assumption that it is possible to have sustainable logging, it is not necessarily the case that jobs are protected only in the short term.
—It is as simple as that. There is nothing profound about it. Trees grow, and you cut them down.

—Senator Boswell says that there is nothing profound about it. That was an unnecessary comment. We do not expect too much profound coming from him. When it comes to higher licence fees, the Commonwealth has been of the view that some States have charged ridiculously low licence fees in forests for far too long. Certainly, the Queensland Government, with which Senator Boswell was associated, was one of the worst culprits in this respect. I would have thought that licence fees, not just in relation to export woodchips but in relation to the exploitation of forests generally, have been too low in Australia for too long.

ANSWER.PARA: That, however, has been remedied in large part in the last couple of years because all State governments have come to the view that resources were going out of the door too cheaply. In terms of the woodchip industry itself, I would have thought that, rather than simply looking at questions of higher licence fees, what the Government, the industry and certainly conservation groups must look at is an improvement in our secondary processing. I would much rather see that happen. Rather than export our jobs elsewhere, we could have them here.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Can the Minister detail steps to be taken to strengthen equal opportunity in the Public Service following a recent serious dispute about the seniority of a position within the Public Service Commission, a bureaucratic confrontation which threatened the viability of the Government's equal opportunity program? Can the Minister give a guarantee that such interdepartmental feuding will not again jeopardise the Government's excellent record on and commitment to equal opportunity in the Public Service?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I perhaps should answer this question in my capacity as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters. The Government's commitment to equal opportunity remains as strong as it ever was, which is well ahead of any other party in this Parliament. It has been the pioneering Government in Australia in establishing the right for opportunity in employment to be created for particular groups who are disadvantaged. Those groups are Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders; people with disabilities, who are traditionally discriminated against; workers from non-English-speaking backgrounds, who also have discrimination visited on them and are not regarded, it seems, by employers on an equal basis with others; and women. The Government is committed to those objectives. Equal opportunity is high on our social justice agenda. It is something that we have pioneered in government and we will continue to do so.

ANSWER.PARA: Since there has been some newspaper speculation-some of that speculation was picked up in the question from Senator Reynolds-may I say that the Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, who is in charge of funding and structures within this area, Minister Wendy Fatin, who is the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, and I, in my capacity as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on Public Service matters, met last night and resolved the matters that were in contention. The result of those discussions is to increase the level at which the equal employment opportunity position should be supervised within the Public Service Commission, and to agree to advertise that position for applicants to apply from both within and outside the Australian Public Service.

The new Public Service Commission structure which has been agreed to as well establishes a balanced arrangement based on a workload that provides for, as I have said, a higher executive representation of equal employment opportunity. The new position will be that of a new First Assistant Commissioner who will be responsible, and designated as being responsible, for human resource policy and who will manage, in addition to the equal employment opportunity responsibilities, issues of staff mobility and recruitment. We have agreed as Ministers that we will provide this new structure, will review it in about two years' time, and see how it is functioning; and if it needs to be changed or improved then, based on its track record, we will do so. I table a press release with the new structure attached to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer the Minister to his statement in the Senate on 14 September last that `$400m per year was being ripped off Australian taxpayers by cheats and bludgers'. Can the Minister please explain the basis for this calculation?

—If one looks at the Budget projections for the next few years as to the amount that we believe can be saved by the introduction of the tax file number system, then that figure of $400m comes into play.
—No, it does not. You estimated $300m less than that.

—No. The current problem, which we have now discussed in here several times, is to do with the best available means of getting a comparison of tax records and social security records, and our problem has been that the best available means so far is to do it all by hand. That has meant one would have to devote an enormous amount of time and, of course, if one wanted to get the kind of money we are talking about now, a huge number of staff to do the job. That has not been possible and therefore we have not been able to get the money. We now have available to us technology that was not available before. That technology should enable us to gain hundreds of millions of dollars a year in the future.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The question I asked concerned the basis on which the $400m was calculated. I wonder whether the Minister could address that particular matter.
—Rubbery.
—I think I heard one interjection saying that it was pretty rubbery. Any estimate of what one can get in the future has to be an estimate; it cannot be anything else.
—What is the basis of the estimate?

—I ask the honourable senator just to listen. It can be determined by looking at what is being done by hand now and projecting what can come about by use of a proper tax file number system with all the safeguards that we have guaranteed in this place in the last few weeks.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I refer to the artificial sweetening substance aspartame, marketed in Australia as Nutrasweet. Has a review taken place in relation to the safety of this product? If so, can the Minister advise of what progress has been made in this review?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fact that in July of this year doubts about the safety of aspartame, which is marketed in the United Kingdom-were reported in the Guardian newspaper. Concerns were expressed by Dr Millstone of Sussex University about the authenticity of original research work on aspartame. I referred these concerns to the Australian Food Standards Committee, as this Committee is responsible for the development and review of food standards in Australia. I am now able to report the outcome of the examination carried out by the food, science and technology subcommittee, which is responsible for providing advice on the assessment of the safety of food additives and contaminates in food. Of course, copies of Dr Millstone's papers were supplied to that subcommittee for review.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that the concerns expressed by Dr Millstone were initially raised by him during the mid-1970s and the issues had been reviewed by the United States Food and Drug Administration in 1979 and 1981, by a public board of inquiry in 1981, and by an investigation conducted by the United States General Accounting Office in 1987. All these United States authorities had rejected the claims made by Dr Millstone. The food, science and technology subcommittee was familiar with these inquiries and their recommendations. There was no new data supplied which had not been considered by the National Health and Medical Research Council when it approved aspartame for use in specific foods at restricted levels in 1981.

No change to present approvals for use of aspartame has been announced by the United States or the United Kingdom Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, who had also reviewed Dr Millstone's data. I believe that consumers who are concerned about Nutrasweet can rely on the expertise of our scientific review.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should get them to use sugar.

—It is not my task to promote Nutrasweet or sugar. I recognise the intervention of a Queensland senator. It is proper for me to allay the fears and misgivings of those many people in the community who turn to alternatives, like Senator Vanstone-whether for sweet or calorie reasons, I do not know-in relation to their food choices, and drinks in particular. Australian and overseas authorities have rejected allegations made by Dr Millstone. I believe that consumers of foods with this additive can have their misgivings laid to rest. The use of Nutrasweet for foods in Australia will continue to be monitored by the food, science and technology subcommittee. Any request for extension of use in other foods will be evaluated by that committee.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. Is it a fact that, despite having about 16,000 employees on the payroll in the Department of Social Security, the Minister's Department recently found it necessary to commission a draft letter relating to claims for overpayment to be prepared by a consultant for a fee of $848? Is the letter currently awaiting ministerial approval? How much has been paid to consultants for similar exercises over the last 12 months?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The presentation of the thousands of forms that come from my Department is a matter of very great concern to me and to the Government. Obviously, when dealing with a clientele of which between 15 per cent and 20 per cent are estimated to have literacy problems, we have to be particularly careful about how we handle forms. When we have a department which is dealing with such a racial mix, we have to be very careful about the forms we send out. When we have a department that is dealing with more than one million aged pensioners, we have to be very careful about the forms sent out.

ANSWER.PARA: Quite apart from introducing into the Parliament a complete rewriting of the Social Security Act to put it into some sort of proper English-I hope that we will be able to get that done this year and I will be pushing that as hard as I can-we are trying to review all of our forms. If in the expenditure of more $20 billion a year we spend $800 on a consultant to draft a letter, so what?

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EIGHTH UNITED NATIONS CONGRESS ON THE PREVENTION OF CRIME AND TREATMENT OF OFFENDERS

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs to the Eighth United Nations Congress on the Prevention of Crime and Treatment of Offenders held in Havana from 27 August to 7 September 1990. Could the Minister inform the Senate of the outcome of the congress and, in particular, comment on the successful Australian initiatives?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly want to take this opportunity to comment on the participation by the Australian delegation in this most important United Nations conference held in Cuba dealing with organised crime and the treatment of offenders. I particularly want to comment on the participation by Senator Barney Cooney, who, at great difficulty and hardship to himself, went to Havana in order to superbly lead the Australian delegation. He was aided in that by the South Australian Attorney-General, Mr Chris Sumner. Ten other members from the Commonwealth, South Australia, Western Australia and New South Wales membership made up the delegation.

ANSWER.PARA: The congress must be regarded as a most successful one. Many international conferences, even national conferences, as honourable senators will know, can just result in resolutions which are grandstanding or platitudinous being passed. But Senator Cooney insisted on behalf of Australia-and got his view across very effectively-that the resolutions of this conference be very practical in their outcome. In particular, the conference looked at modern bilateral treaties and the help that we could give to those countries which did not have a practice of treaty negotiation in these matters.

As a result the congress adopted two model bilateral treaties on extradition and mutual assistance in criminal matters which had been sponsored by Australia. These are the model treaties which Australia uses in its own treaty negotiating program. They are designed to ensure that there should be no safe haven in the world for those who indulge in criminal activities, particularly nefarious criminal activities such as drug trafficking and major fraud, and that offenders should not be able to escape due punishment by fleeing to some safe haven where extradition treaties are not in place. The mutual assistance in criminal matters treaties are also a very important part of the necessary international cooperation in dealing with these criminal activities where the criminals, of course, do not regard national boundaries as any threat or hindrance to their activities. Of course, governments have to take the same point of view.

In view of the importance of these two model treaties sponsored by Australia and adopted by that particular conference, they have been referred by the Congress to the United Nations General Assembly separately, rather than by way of inclusion in its general report. The contribution made by Australia to the successful outcome of both the Congress and associated workshops was the subject of favourable comment both by other delegations as well as by the secretariat. It was an excellent example. I hope it is a precursor to the meetings which are to be held later this month between the Prime Minister and the Premiers. It is an excellent example of cooperation between the Commonwealth and the States in the achievement of objectives in a recognised international forum. I hope to present to the Senate a formal report on that congress at a later time.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: JOBS, EDUCATION AND TRAINING SCHEME: SOLE PARENT PENSIONERS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. Can he explain why less than five per cent of Australia's approximately 250,000 sole parent pensioners are currently involved in the jobs, education and training (JET) scheme, and of these only half are from the Department's designated target group who suffer a particular labour market disadvantage?

—The JET scheme, which has not been in operation for all that long, is an important step in how the Government assists those women who are receiving the sole parent pension but who wish to gain employment. We are still speaking predominantly about women in looking at sole parent pensions; it is only 3 per cent or 4 per cent of such pensioners who are not women. In the first 9,000 interviews under the JET program, approximately 6,000 women indicated that they would undertake some training if it were to become available to them. The others basically indicated that parenting was for them the way they wished to proceed. I think it is the Government's duty to look at those women and to respect their wishes on either side of that equation. For those who have been seeking training, the JET program has been introduced. It will be expanded over time and, hopefully, the Government will be able to take into account the needs of all those women who will seek some training. In doing that, at the same time we will have to build up the scheme as we build up the numbers in child-care-the Government has already announced some schemes to do that-because obviously the lack of child-care can sometimes act as a disincentive for those women who may be seeking employment. So the initial reactions to the JET program are encouraging, encouraging enough certainly for the Government to seek to expand it over the coming years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the Treasurer's announcement of an inquiry by the Martin Committee-the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration-into the Australian banking system, and I ask the Minister whether the terms of reference will be wide enough to cover the allegedly corrupt bank management practices put on record by Senator Paul McLean and supported by 80 affidavits tabled in the Senate? In view of the Treasurer's commitment to continuing the regime of high interest rates, does the Minister agree that the referral to a committee which will report several months and possibly a year hence, is little more than a device to get the issue off the political agenda? Does the Minister agree that Australian industry, small business and primary producers are in urgent need of interest rate relief? Is the Government prepared to refer immediately to the Prices Surveillance Authority the specific issue of the banks' operating margins, which are now almost double what they were in 1988 and among the highest in the world?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler has asked me a number of questions about bank interest rates and the proposed inquiry by a parliamentary committee. The answer to the first part of the question asked by Senator Spindler, relating to the widening of terms of reference to cover corrupt bank practices put on record by Senator McLean,-`Will those terms of reference be widened to cover that?'-is no. The terms of reference are yet to be finalised by the Treasurer and they will be made public in due course, but that is not what the inquiry is about.

ANSWER.PARA: In the second part of the question, Senator Spindler makes the allegation that the referral of the committee is some sort of political exercise to get the interest rate issue off the political agenda. The answer to that question is no. The issue for the committee is not whether interest rates should remain relatively high. After all, that is a matter for the Government to determine, in terms of the tightness of monetary policy, and there has been a statement made by the Minister and the Government every second day about that for the last 18 months. The issue for the committee is the question of competitiveness within the banking system following deregulation of the banking sector and the admission of foreign banks. That is the issue which the committee will be fundamentally addressing.

Finally, Senator Spindler asked whether I agreed that small business and primary producers are in urgent need of interest rate relief and whether this issue could be referred to the Prices Surveillance Authority. The answer is that this issue will not be referred to the Prices Surveillance Authority. As the Treasurer has stated on numerous occasions and as I have stated on numerous occasions here, no-one wants interest rates to remain high for longer than necessary because of the sorts of consequences-often difficult and sad consequences-pointed out by Senator Spindler in the body of his question.

A Treasury Reserve Bank analysis of recent trends in bank lending margins has revealed, in summary, the following information: namely, bank margins have widened since the end of 1989. To date, the rise in average margins has increased bank revenue by $160m above what it would otherwise have been. If these greater margins were maintained, their effect would be to increase bank revenue by around $1,000m in a full year, and that figure would almost totally compensate for the increase of bad debts on bank books, estimated currently to be $1,200m.

Those are matters of fact which might help Senator Spindler in his consideration of this matter. I think it is important to have those facts on the record, as distinct from some wild allegations that have been made about some of these matters on all sides of politics.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Did the Minister recently address the annual dinner of the Victorian branch of the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors (AFCC)? Did he use that address to announce that the Australian Government had drawn up a reform strategy for the construction industry? Can he advise honourable senators what the elements of this strategy are?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can say is that this must be the best question in Question Time today. I just want the record to show that it came from the Government side. The answer to the question is: first, yes; secondly, yes; and, thirdly, let me enlarge on it. It is well known that this Government has shown greater policy initiative, greater courage and greater foresight on micro-economic reform than any other government in the history of this country. Events over the last few weeks bear that out.

ANSWER.PARA: We believe, and I said to the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors, that the building and construction industry in Australia should not be exempt from going through a process of micro-economic reform. We see it as basically a cost-plus industry able to pass its costs on to the consumers of buildings. On average, there is between 20 and 30 per cent lost time on central business district construction costs around Australia. In this industry there is little or no on the job training and little or no research and development. There is great employment insecurity in this industry, leading to work practices that at times encourage projects to be prolonged beyond their normal expectation. It is an industry typified by the lowest tender winning the job, but with a capacity for rise and fall provisions in its final contract arrangements, which usually means rise and rise provisions. It is typified by problems between contractors and subcontractors, bankruptcy and a high accident level.

Many of the corporate high-fliers of recent memory have helped tarnish Australia's international reputation. Where funds are borrowed abroad to support major construction projects in Australia, we are now finding that the lenders of those finances are citing the spectacularly unsuccessful records of some of the corporate high-fliers as reasons why they want to see some change in Australia before they lend to those types of entrepreneurs.

On the basis of all this, I have put a reform package to the building industry, both to the AFCC, which Senator Burns has asked me about-and that was at a dinner-and to the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia, which is the dominant union in the industry, at a lunch.

The terms of our reform package are that the industry should adhere to the new employment practices that are proposed, the new ways of working on the sites that we are proposing and the new industrial relations principles that are being proposed. If it does not, we as a Commonwealth Government, as a major consumer of buildings in Australia, and of our own volition-but where we have support from State Governments too-will exclude from our tender bid list those companies that do not affirm those practices. We will, in effect, hold the ring in terms of fair play in the Australian building and construction industry.

I might say that a number of leading companies in Australia-a number of resource development companies-have also said that they would be interested in joining us in holding that ring too to ensure fair play for all.

The strategy that we have in mind will be policed by a national tripartite body to oversee it. It will have specific working committees coordinating the industrial relations aspects of reform, and the levels and areas of Government assistance and involvement in the process. We will-in concert with construction companies who wish to be part of this reform, and with the building unions that have affirmed that there is a need for these sorts of changes-be establishing model construction sites. We believe it is not simply a matter of proclaiming policy objectives but, rather, it is a matter of having demonstration examples of what those reform practices can achieve.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a point of order. The Minister is debating the question. I ask that you ask him to bring his answer to the question to a close.
—The question was clearly within the Minister's portfolio, but I remind him that he is making a very long answer.

—I will bring my answer to a conclusion, Mr President. We are proposing to establish, with companies and with the unions concerned, model construction sites to trial the new work processes to demonstrate to others that they can succeed in achieving significant economies. We are having talks with the States, unions and employers over a national superannuation, redundancy and severance pay arrangement, too, to provide some guarantees of employment continuity for a core work force in the industry.

ANSWER.PARA: I conclude my answer by inviting the Senate to draw the contrast between a positive, forward-looking micro-economic reform effort involving the employers and the unions with the Government and the type of inquisition being developed in New South Wales by the Greiner Government in the form of a royal commission which will be the thirtieth inquiry into the building industry in the last 10 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. I refer him to the recent increases in petrol prices as a result of the Gulf crisis and the subsequent increases in world oil prices. I also refer him to the fact that Australia already produces enough oil to meet the equivalent of 90 per cent of our domestic needs, and that oil imported from the Gulf to Australia would only be in negligible quantities. I ask the Minister: In view of these facts, why, then, are Australian consumers once again being asked by the Government to shoulder another financial burden by paying higher prices for petrol which would have come not from the Gulf but, instead, from our own shores?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can tell Senator Bjelke-Petersen that not all things that the Fraser Government did do we criticise. We have continued the Fraser Government policy of world parity pricing for Australian oil. We have gone further; we have deregulated the local oil market in Australia, which is something that the Fraser Government did not have the courage to do. This means that Australian oil producers are able to trade their product on the world market and/or obtain world parity pricing for it within Australia. Thus, the value of oil produced in Australia is at world rates not at some artificially lower rate contrived by overt regulation-which might be what the National Party of Australia would prefer in an area of its interests, but is not what a government committed to a mixed economy with a strong free enterprise dimension wants to see.

ANSWER.PARA: As I say, this means that Australian oil prices follow world trends. The prices we are seeing at present on the spot market are not to be regarded as any indication of what the longer term price for oil will be on the world market. Indeed, the truth is that supply of oil in the world is currently matching demand, notwithstanding the fact that we are moving into a northern winter in which traditionally there is a higher demand for oil. Supply is matching demand. What we are seeing is speculator activity on the spot market where the faintest of rumour or a whiff of a gunshot in the Gulf causes the spot market to reflect all sorts of speculator instability in prices. It is not a basis for making a long term policy and it is not a basis for this Government to change any of its commitments to world parity pricing and a free market in Australian petroleum products.

Iraq's prior payment performance in relation to wheat sales have been exemplary, and despite the uncertain situation in the Gulf the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) is treating the situation as a temporary suspension rather than a cessation of its contracts with Iraq and expects that in time normal commercial relations will be resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 September Senator Coulter asked me a question regarding greenhouse gas research. The answer inevitably is a long answer and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The reply read as follows-

The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has been the main international forum for discussion and development of the greenhouse issue. Australia has provided strong diplomatic and technical support to the IPCC process including strong support to Working Group I which undertook a scientific assessment of the greenhouse problem. Indeed, Australia was one of five areas in the world singled out for calculation of the likely climatic results of various greenhouse scenarios. Australia was chosen because of the advanced climate modelling work done by CSIRO and the Bureau of Meteorology; that is some indication of Australia's scientific standing in this field.

The Government is giving a high priority to ensuring that national, southern hemisphere and regional concerns are taken into account internationally. We have promised to provide at least $5.7m over the next three years for greenhouse research. In 1989-90 the Government provided $3.462m to funding core research on monitoring of greenhouse induced climate change. The research is being undertaken through CSIRO, Bureau of Meteorology and the Department of Defence's Permanent Committee on Tides and Mean Sea Level.

This research involves modelling of the climate system, research into regional climate processes and monitoring of the climate system to identify special regional characteristics. In addition, modelling to improve regional predictions for greenhouse induced climate change and linking with overseas ocean circulation and climate models is being developed. Other work currently being done by CSIRO is on providing control strategies to limit emissions. A major factor in this is improving the efficiency of resource utilisation practices.

A national research grants scheme is being established and is to be operative this year under the administration of the National Greenhouse Advisory Committee. The scheme will complement existing greenhouse research, by focusing on research that is ineligible for support from either core research funds or other existing grant schemes. Proposals for funding must relate to research into understanding the scientific processes which underlie greenhouse induced climate change, understanding the impacts and development of adaptation and mitigation responses. Over 100 expressions of interest have been received and are currently being considered.

Greenhouse research may also be funded under other programs, for example the Grants for Industrial Research and Development (GIRD) Scheme. The Government has decided to establish a new generic technology within the GIRD scheme on Waste and Environmental Management Technology. The Industry Research and Development Board has allocated $3.5m for projects to be approved this year. All projects will involve a commercial firm and are aimed at the development of commercially exploitable technology.

Senator Coulter's question referred to activities which I have initiated, but naturally many of my colleagues also have an interest in these issues. Greenhouse gas research projects in areas such as: renewable energy (solar, hydro-electricity, wind and biomass); energy efficiency improvements; natural gas in vehicles and methane collection from mines have been funded by the Government under the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Program (NERDDP). To date, a total of over $74m (since 1978) out of a total NERDDP budget of around $250m has been directed at greenhouse related research to assist Australia develop timely and cost effective energy responses.

Commonwealth, State and Territory energy departments are also working together to identify areas where further reductions can be achieved and current programs and policies enhanced. In particular, energy departments are targeting energy efficiency in domestic appliances, new homes, commercial buildings and passenger vehicles. The Australian Mineral and Energy Council (AMEC) have produced a report which provides details on current and proposed action to address greenhouse gas emissions from the energy sector.

AMEC is but one of a number of bodies, including ANZEC, the Victorian Solar Energy Council, the Prime Minister's Science Council and the Prime Minister's Working Group on Greenhouse Gas Emissions, which are investigating the development of climate change issues in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston asked me a question on 19 September regarding pensioner health benefit (PHB) cards being received by pensioners not entitled to receive them. I have an answer for him. The announcement in the Budget of new arrangements to maximise the income of pensioners was accompanied by a commitment that no existing pensioner health benefit card holders would lose their cards because of the changes. Because many pensioners might want to get a higher return on their investments and would act to do so after the Budget, arrangements had to be operating from 22 August to ensure that PHB cards were not withdrawn where income increased above the fringe benefit level of $95 for this purpose. It would be unfair that pensioners who maximise their income before 1 March 1991 implementation date would lose their eligibility for the PHB card.

ANSWER.PARA: Changes were made to the pensions computer system on 22 August to ensure that cards were not withdrawn. As a result, a very small number of people over the PHB income limits for reasons not associated with the income maximisation changes were issued with PHB cards by the Department of Social Security (DSS) through its computer system. This is because by Budget night we had to have in place a system which ensured that current PHB card holders would not lose their cards. Because of time constraints, it was not possible to develop a computer program which differentiated between those who went over the fringe benefit limits after maximising their income in response to deeming and those who exceeded the limits for other reasons.

A computer program that can differentiate will be developed by October. The computer systems changes involved are complex and require considerable development and testing. DSS staff have been instructed to ask for the return of cards from persons who are not eligible and where they come to notice. The cards which are not returned will be valid only till the end of 1990. It should be appreciated that less than 14 per cent of the total pensioner population do not attract PHB eligibility. Of those only a very small number have been issued with cards. My Department is currently investigating the actual number involved. Although precise figures are not available, it is unlikely that there will be any significant additional cost to the States. There will be a very small additional cost to the Commonwealth for pharmaceuticals.

When consultations are held with State governments soon about longer term rationalisation of fringe benefit eligibility, the situation I have described will be explained. I am sure that all honourable senators, including Senator Alston, would be more concerned if those who were entitled to keep their cards had lost them. The Government has acted to protect those whom it promised in the Budget to protect.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, I give notice that 15 sitting days after today I shall move that certain delegated legislation, a list of which I shall hand to the Clerk, be disallowed. I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The Committee is taking action because such notices must be given within 15 sitting days of tabling. The notices are in respect of six instruments made within four portfolios. Some of the Committee's concerns relate to possible breaches of personal liberties. In one of these instruments a statutory authority is given an inappropriate power to demand certain information from any person. In another a public official is given an apparent power to determine whether a person is guilty of an offence. One instrument does not appear to provide a right of review of an adverse exercise by a public official of a discretion to waive or remit fees. Other concerns of the Committee relate to parliamentary proprieties. In one case, material may have been incorporated invalidly. In another, payment of Commonwealth money may have been authorised twice. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short statement of the concerns of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Wool Marketing Regulations (Amendment)
Statutory Rules 1990 No. 203

These Regulations, among other things, provide that the Australian Wool Corporation may direct any person to provide information relating to the wool tax payments on wool sold under the Reserve Price Scheme. A penalty of $1,000 is provided for failure to comply with a direction.

This is a very wide power which may be unintentional due to a drafting oversight. The Explanatory Statement which accompanies the Regulations advises that the intention of this provision is to enable the AWC to seek this information only from registered wool brokers. Such a provision would have been reasonable and appropriate. However, the actual drafting of the provision empowers the AWC to require information from any person at all.

The Committee questions whether such a wide power was intended. If it was, then the Committee would require detailed justification for such a power being granted to a statutory authority. If it was not, then the Regulations should be amended. In any event, the Committee asks why there is a discrepancy between a provision of an instrument affecting personal liberties and the explanation of that provision in the Explanatory Statement.
Control of Naval Waters Regulations (Amendment)
Statutory Rules 1990 No. 206
These Regulations are made under powers contained in the Control of Naval Waters Amendment Act 1978. That Act remained unproclaimed for more than 12 years, until 1 August 1990.

The Regulations provide that the Superintendent of Naval Waters may cause to be removed from certain waters, or from the foreshore of those waters, persons who ``have contravened these Regulations.'' The parent Act, as amended in 1978, authorises the making of Regulations in those terms. Nevertheless, the drafting of the Regulations, while within power, may be a breach of personal liberties. If the power is to remove people who have been charged and convicted of contravening the Regulations, then such a provision may be fair. The actual drafting, however, appears defective. As drafted, it appears that the Superintendent is the judge of whether an offence has, or has not, occurred.

It is a basic principle of personal liberty that a person is innocent until proven guilty in a court of competent jurisdiction. In this case the Committee believes that the Regulations should be amended to clarify their intention.
Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Regulations
Statutory Rules 1990 No. 231

These Regulations provide administrative detail for a scheme established by their parent Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act 1989 for the notification and assessment of industrial chemicals. The scheme is intended to protect public health and people at work.

The Regulations prescribe fees for purposes of the scheme. Some of these are very substantial. In one case the fee is $28,000, in another $25,000. The Regulations give the Director an unfettered discretion to waive or remit fees. The only criteria for the exercise of the discretion is that the Director must think it ``fit'' to do so. There is no provision for Administrative Appeals Tribunal review of this discretion.

The Committee always questions provisions which grant discretions to public officials with no external right of review of the merits of an adverse decision. In this case there is the additional deficiency that there are no suitable criteria to limit or guide the exercise of the discretions once the conditions for their exercise arise. In addition, it may be that in this case the Regulations could provide for mandatory waiver or remission of fees once certain objective criteria had been met. The parent Act properly provides for AAT review of important discretions. In these circumstances it may be appropriate for the Regulations to be amended to remove the discretions altogether or at least to provide for AAT review.
Determination TAFE 7/90 under s.13 of the States Grants (Technical and Further Education Assistance) Act 1989
Determination TAFE 8/90 under s.13 of the States Grants (Technical and Further Education Assistance) Act 1989

These Determinations approve technical and further education proposals and determine amounts to be paid to different States in 1990 in respect of the proposals. The earlier Determination, TAFE 7/90, determines $1,621,040 for eight projects in four States. Determination TAFE 8/90, made three weeks later, determines $2,699,852 for eleven projects in five States. Five of the projects appear to be approved and to have identical amounts determined in both Determinations. The Frankston College of TAFE had $46,135 determined in TAFE 7/90 and then another $46,135 determined in TAFE 8/90. Logan, Rockhampton and Balga Colleges of TAFE similarly had projects approved and amounts of $277,500, $341,625 and $297,280 determined twice in three weeks. Hobart Technical College (Clarence Campus) had $195,500 approved twice. A single Explanatory Statement nine lines long was provided for 10 of these Determinations, which determine some $300 million.

It is a breach of parliamentary propriety if delegated legislation is not clear in its effect and accompanied by adequate explanatory material. On the face of the later instrument there is no intention to restate or amend the amounts in the earlier Determination. The legal effect of the later Determination appears to be to approve a cumulative payment of equal amounts.
Livestock Export (Merino) Orders (Amendment)
Livestock Export Orders No. 2 of 1990
The Committee questioned the validity of some aspects of these Orders.

Some instruments of delegated legislation incorporate other material, which then becomes part of Commonwealth legislation. In the last year the Committee has scrutinised several instruments which have incorporated thousands of pages of material. Such incorporation is legally valid insofar as the material is already in existence at the date the instrument comes into effect. The incorporation of future material, or material as amended from time to time in the future, is invalid unless such material is part of an Act or a regulation or rule made under an Act. In addition, the parent Act may expressly authorise incorporation of future material or material as amended from time to time.

The present instrument incorporates a variety of material. Some of this incorporation is valid, such as an already published set of auction dates designated as such by the Australian Association of Stud Merino Breeders Ltd (``the AASMBL''). Other material is less obviously valid. An auction is required to be subject to the ``Guidelines and Conditions for Export Sales,'' determined and published by the AASMBL. Neither the instrument nor the Explanatory Statement indicates whether that is an existing publication. There would also problems if it was intended to amend the Guidelines. A further problem appears to exist with another provision which refers to dates for auctions ``as published prior to the commencement of each subsequent export ram selling season...'' Such publications were not in existence at the time the present Orders came into effect.

The Committee seeks clarification of these incorporations, in particular whether there is some provision in the parent Act or Regulations which authorises what may be invalid provisions. It may be appropriate to amend the instrument to place its validity beyond doubt.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am in continuation, and the technical aspects of the Dried Fruits Levy Amendment Bill have been discussed previously. I continue the debate by saying that no-one has to be told that Australia's rural communities are in crisis. Commodity prices are plummeting while interest rates, labour costs and other inputs are rising, and the Australian dollar is at a record all-time high. Much of Australia's rural future depends on the subsidies problem being addressed in the coming General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) round of discussions. Its future will hinge on the abolition of subsidies and price support schemes. Currently, we are seeing trade-offs between the United States and its farmers, and the European Community and its farmers are having discussions at present.

SPEECH.PARA: The future of Australia's rural industry depends fairly heavily on a successful round of the GATT negotiations. What is going to come out of these negotiations? That is what the world is asking. Many people are saying it will be a win for free trade. Some are predicting that GATT is dead and that failed negotiations will mean an increase in tariffs and protectionism. The question also has to be asked: Will the smaller nations, in agricultural world trade terms, be able to force the United States and the European Community into making some concessions to cut subsidies and protection? These are the questions that need to be answered.

Australia's agricultural industry is fast becoming a dying industry, not only because of the Government's financial incompetence-that has played a fairly massive role-but because of international pressures. The effect of the subsidy war between America and Europe is being felt in Australia-and not only on the broadacre farms; it is reaching a crisis point and devastating smaller industries. Sultanas, apricots and currants are joining the long list of Australian horticultural industries which are suffering from cheap, dumped and subsidised imports flooding onto Australia's domestic market. The list is endless: pineapples-Senator Kernot recognises the position of the pineapple growers-bananas, strawberries, peanuts, dairy products, rice--

TALK.START.PARA: —Potatoes.

— I know that Senator Bell is concerned about potatoes because he comes from Tasmania. The list also includes orange, apple juice, and Canadian pork, and even the humble navy bean is being subsidised by overseas countries. Queensland growers tell me that the pea and bean industries are now suffering huge cuts in their production. Last quarter alone an extra 1,000 tonnes of imported frozen peas and beans came into Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Acting Deputy President, I know that you will be surprised to learn that every month Australia imports $150m worth of foodstuffs. That is $2 billion a year. It is 10 per cent of our trading deficit, and it is food that Australia can produce. This bill is made up not of caviar and champagne but of everyday foods that are appearing on the supermarket shelves. One has to question the community responsibility of some of our chain grocery stores and their attitudes in this matter. The numbers are here for all Australians to look at. Let us look at the dried fruit industry, as we are discussing the Dried Fruit Levy Amendment Bill. Let us take currants, for example. In the growing year ending--

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—I want to talk to the Minister about this privately. I have some problems with his Department, but I will discuss that later with him. In February of 1989, 566 tonnes of currants were imported into Australia. The majority of these came from Greece. At the end of the 1990 growing year, the figure has almost doubled to 957 tonnes; 827 tonnes also came from Greece. The amount is almost 25 per cent of the Australian market for currants, and most of those imports attract an export subsidy of $1,300 a tonne. How can our farmers compete against that?

SPEECH.PARA: Let us take sultanas. In the last growing year, 4,968 tonnes of sultanas were imported into Australia and 1,846 tonnes of apricots also were imported. Most of these came from Turkey, where rural interest rates are subsidised down to 5 per cent, and they are available to the farming community. Our farmers have to face rates of around 22 per cent, and they are losing their farms. They are not only losing their product onto the shelves, they are now losing their farms.

Australian farmers are losing markets progressively to imported foods which are sent to Australia with the added backing of export subsidies, or which are just plain dumped. Not only do schemes like this cost government a lot of money, but also they mean that a product is more expensive to buy in the country of origin than it is on the world market.

Last year, the Japanese Government spent over $6 billion subsidising its domestic rice market. A kilo of rice bought in Japan costs six times the world market price. The cost of the United States farm Bill ranks in billions of dollars. The total direct payment to wheat growers reached a high of $3.86 billion in 1986 and payments to corn growers in 1987 were $7.74 billion.

I hope that the negotiations to reduce agricultural subsidies and protection for farm products are going on. The three largest trading nations in the world are blissfully continuing their supportive practices and have not made much noise in the way of concessions. The negotiations are due to be completed in December, and one of the negotiation groups is discussing agriculture at the GATT Conference. There is no set agenda, however, and countries have made submissions on the amount they are willing to give.

There are few people who would argue that free trade is the ultimate goal where goods are exchanged openly and fairly. If this were to occur, every Australian farmer would be about 300 per cent better off. There would be no limit to the demand for Australian products. But there is no gain in being the only country which makes these moves. The world has to move towards free trade-we all agree with that. The Democrats are supporting that too. We have to move with a united conviction to that goal, but Australia is out in front with a banner and drum and no-one else is joining the parade. The rates of assistance in Japan are estimated to have decreased from a staggering 76 per cent in 1986 to a current level of 72 per cent, a drop of 4 per cent. The Japanese have really taken a stick to their protection!

The European Community's assistance rate is estimated to be 38 per cent-a reduction from 48 per cent in 1989. America's rate is 27 per cent. It has reduced it from 40 per cent in 1987. The three major trading blocs are setting the standard of rates of assistance with the average rate worldwide of 39 per cent. Australia has done the right thing. We have shown our credentials, and we have made a real commitment to free trade with a rate of assistance to agriculture measured at 10 per cent in 1989. I just want to mention some of the things that we have done to reduce our rates of assistance. Market price support for dairy produce as well as domestic pricing for wheat and sugar have been removed. I did not necessarily agree with it.
Senator Kernot interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —With the support of the Australian Democrats, we were able to secure for the sugar industry some sort of protection. Price underwriting for wheat has been replaced by a government guarantee. Tariffs for dried fruit, tobacco and citrus juices have been reduced. The import embargo on sugar has been replaced by a specific declining tariff. In New South Wales, the main egg producers have abolished all production pricing and monopoly powers of the Egg Corporation. All of these measures will considerably reduce the level of assistance in Australia, which currently has the second lowest level in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development range of countries. New Zealand has the lowest level with 5 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: While we have only a number of small countries cutting back their tariff levels, the big producers are continuing their subsidies and support programs and are gaining a particularly unfair advantage. A glut in wheat production in both the Northern and Southern Hemispheres together with the impact of the United States (US) subsidies has prompted a drop in wheat prices to a 40-year low. US prices for export wheat are expected to average $124 a tonne in 1990-91. Farmers are receiving $30 a tonne from the Government of the United States of America.

Not only has our wheat industry been hit; we are also exposing our industries to an increased disease risk. The acceptable risk policy which has been adopted by the Government is inevitably exposing our farmers to trouble. The Federal Government is playing Russian roulette with the agricultural industries in Australia. Every time we raise the subject of disease, Senator Cook jumps up and down and accuses the Opposition of trying to use quarantine as a trade barrier. I do not think he knows the first thing about rural industry. That is not what we are on about. The Minister simply does not understand what the effect will be of diseases such as transmittable gastroenteritis on the pork industry, black sigatoka and moko disease on our banana industry, fire-blight on the apple industry, or even the threat of disease on our valuable disease-free status in world agricultural trade. People buy from us because they know they are going to get a disease-free product.

This Government has made a decision to lift a longstanding embargo on fresh, chilled and frozen pork from Canada. There are 22 subsidies going to the Canadian pork producers. There is an 8c a kilogram countervailing duty levied by the American Government, but we have let the pork in here for free despite the risk that it can carry transmittable gastroenteritis, commonly known as TGE. The majority of State government veterinary officials and Department of Primary Industries and Energy officers strongly recommended against the importation of fresh pig meat, yet Senator Cook, with his gung ho attitude, said that it was going to be an acceptable risk. It is not his risk; he is not carrying the risk.

Another problem we have is that of countries classified as developing. If that is the case, they are automatically given a 5 per cent reduction of tariff for all imports coming into Australian markets. One hundred countries are on the list, including the Bahamas, Korea, Hong Kong, Singapore and Saudi Arabia-the richest country in the world; no, it is the second richest. Brunei is the richest, and it gets subsidies too. Our farmers are granting cheap entry into our domestic market to the richest man in the world, the Sultan of Brunei. America and New Zealand both cut off the developing country tariff preference once a product from a developing country has captured 20 per cent of the market, but developing countries can take 100 per cent of the market in Australia. They are doing that or are going to do it in some of our industries.

Our domestic horticultural industries are on the verge of bankruptcy now, and they will not be sustainable. Australian rural production in 1989-90 was $23.87 billion with the rural sector contributing some $15 billion to our exports. While our farmers are contributing this much to our economy and working hard to adjust the positive side of our balance of trade, they are paying an average of $6,000 per year for tariffs on farm inputs. I want to say that everyone wants free trade. It is desirable. It is important for our rural industries and for our exporters. Yet what price are we going to pay for this goal? We have already played all our bargaining chips. We have shown our hand and reduced our tariffs below the target level before the negotiations have been concluded. It is not a very good poker player that exposes his hand without getting a guarantee.

While this attitude may let some of our officials have a warm inner glow, it is not doing a lot for Australia's rural industry. Free trade is fine. We all support it. Tariff reduction is fine. But the continued viability of our industries is also essential, and the two different objectives must both be achieved. We have already made our commitment and, by the way, so has New Zealand. Its economy is in a worse state than ours.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not possible.

—It is getting close to being possible. We must travel the road of free trade because it is the only way the rest of the world is going to get a sensible price on commodities-unlike Japan, which at the moment is paying something between $60 and $100 for a kilogram of beef. We have to travel the road because smaller underdeveloped countries are going to be able to sustain an agrarian economy to give their people some hope for the future and some goal to achieve. They are not going to get into any high technology. Most importantly of all, the road to free trade must be travelled if Australia is going to play its role in what it does best: supplying the rest of the world with a premium quality primary product at true prices that grant Australia's farmers a fair day's pay for a fair day's work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the Dried Fruits Levy Amendment Bill 1990, which seeks to increase the levy on dried fruits from $5 to a maximum of $10 per tonne. I want to pick up some of the remarks made by Senator Boswell and others because it is very concerning to hear the tortuous and illogical path woven by members both of the Government and of the Opposition in an attempt to, in some sense, reconcile the idea of an ideological commitment to free trade and market forces on the one hand and protection of rural industries on the other hand. It is an ideological position which is not reconcilable, and I think Senator Boswell's speech a moment ago indicates just that.

SPEECH.PARA: Rather, the position that we should be taking is one in which we seek to serve the interests of Australians-we are, after all, the Federal Parliament of Australia-and also seek to provide a level of independence and self-sufficiency in each country, which is not necessarily served by the objects of free trade, however defined. Senator Boswell did not define what he meant by free trade, but I want to get into that in a moment.

What is usually meant by `free trade'-we have heard this both explicitly and implicitly from members of the Government and members of the Opposition-is the comparison of the end price, the retail price of goods. If the price is higher in one country than another, then the country which has the lower price simply takes a larger slice of the market in a market situation. In the case of the Australian fruit industry, which is what we are discussing here, as Senator Boswell has pointed out, we have seen the importation of such things as dried apricots from Turkey and orange juice concentrate from several South American countries at prices well below the price at which the Australian producer evidently can produce. Members of the Opposition and members of the Government have criticised Australian producers as being inefficient, as judged by that retail price.

Many legitimate costs go into production in various countries. One cost, which we are dealing with in this Bill, is a levy to do certain things in relation to dried fruits. Other costs are legitimately and rightfully borne in the production of rural products in this country. We have certain requirements as to wages and working conditions. Do members of the Opposition want Australian workers to work for $2 a day, as happens in many competitor countries, which go into the cost structure of the products which they produce?

Turkey, which produces dried apricots, has the worst record in the world of mine disasters. Several months ago some hundreds of people were killed in a mine disaster. The conditions which we rightly impose on Australian miners translate through into the cost of electric power, part of which is used by the rural industry and is therefore partly reflected in the price of things such as dried fruits. Do we want to adopt the very low standards of industrial health of Turkey simply to compete? Of course we do not.

We rightly impose conditions in relation to environmental standards. We do not allow the application of certain pesticides and herbicides in this country. We have stringent controls over the registration and regulation of those pesticides, all of which translate into the costs which are borne-and rightly borne-by the rural industry.

The glib words `free trade' need to be heavily qualified. I use this opportunity to ask members of the Government and the Opposition when they talk about free trade to think more in terms of the legitimate costs which go into production in each country and, in striking tariffs, not merely to arbitrarily reduce tariffs-say, to strike them at 40 per cent and reduce them to 25 per cent, 15 per cent and then zero per cent. If we are serious about a level playing field and we are competing equitably with other countries, then surely we need that tariff protection which exactly and correctly represents the costs legitimately put on to Australian producers which are not borne in other countries. That may well mean striking a tariff of 16.25 per cent, or some arbitrary and inexact figure such as that which represents the costs which are legitimately borne by Australian producers. Under those circumstances we have no doubt-I share this view with Senator Boswell -that Australian producers, primary producers, are more than adequately able to compete on world markets. We should certainly not be merely arbitrarily reducing tariffs, assuming that the product price, the retail price, is a fair representation of the efficiency of production and the adequacy of the protection of worker health, environmental health and the other factors which go into that production.

This dried fruits levy is just one of the costs which are borne in Australia and it should be reflected in a tariff which protects the Australian producer against imports. If we were to modify our attitudes in relation to the term `free trade' to that extent, then we might agree that we could all compete on a level playing field and, indeed, Australian primary producers would be much better off.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Dried Fruits Levy Amendment Bill 1990, I am very pleased to have the opportunity to support my Senate leader, Senator Boswell, in the comments he has made in respect of this particular Bill and the dried fruit industry and also in respect of the plight of primary producers throughout this country.
