As Senator Boswell has said, we have seen reductions in the level of subsidy for Japanese primary producers over the last couple of years from 76 per cent to 72 per cent, while at the same time the average level of government input to farm income in this country is one per cent. Let me take, for example, the banana industry, which is worth over $100m to this country every year. The banana growers in north Queensland have put up with low prices and with the effects of cyclones for the last couple of years and have not been complaining. They are very concerned at the moment that their industry will be undermined by imports from Equador and elsewhere-countries where the diseases of black sigatoka and moko are rampant. If Senator Cook and this Government believe that these are not real concerns of Australian banana growers, then they are wrong.

For the benefit of the Government, let me outline the consequences of moko being introduced into this country. Moko is not a disease like black sigatoka which affects the leaf, nor is it a disease like panama which will affect the fruit: moko is a disease that gets into the soil. Once this disease is in the soil, there is no known way of eradicating it. That means that if we allow these cheap banana imports to come in from Ecuador-bananas that have no proper testing and no proper export control-then we run the very real risk of introducing moko into the soil in this country and devastating the banana growing areas of Australia for 10, 20 or 30 years to come. I ask, and the banana growers of north Queensland ask: Is this a reasonable risk for us to be taking? The answer, quite clearly, has to be no.

I disagree with Senator Coulter in one respect: I do not believe that proper protection of primary industry is incompatible with free trade. We in the National Party of Australia accept and believe that free trade is essential for the future of this world as we go into the next century, but we believe that it is also important to have fair trade and safe trade. What this Government does not offer us is safe trade in agricultural products, nor does it offer us fair trade.

As we have already seen, the level of subsidy to overseas primary producers-especially in the United States of America and the European Community (EC)-is wholly unacceptable compared with what Australian primary producers have to put up with. It is not just the level of subsidy about which we have grave concerns; it is also the level of costs, because Australian primary producers face a much higher borrowing cost. For example, while in this country it costs 18 to 20 per cent to run an overdraft account, a primary producer in Europe-in the EC-can run an overdraft account at 10 per cent. Of course, this has dire implications for all of those Australian primary industries that are on the ropes, because it is just another nail in the coffin of Australian farmers.

Australian primary producers are the most cost efficient primary producers in the world. It is said of the Ukraine that it is the bread basket of Europe. Here in Australia we have the potential to supply large portions of the world with all the wheat, wool, peanuts, citrus fruits and dried fruits that it needs, yet Australian primary producers are having grave difficulties surviving because, at a time when things are toughest, the Government allows cheap imports to flood Australian markets. At a time when peanuts are ploughed back into the fields or allowed to rot in Kingaroy because farmers cannot get a market, we find cheap imported peanuts from China, the United States and Israel being allowed to flood this market and sit on the shelves under the label- and I find it rather ironic-`home brand' peanut paste, when, of course, the last thing they are is from home. This is the legacy for which this Government will be condemned by primary producers across this country.

I turn, in particular, to the problem of the dried fruits industry. I received in my Cairns office a representation from some manufacturers of dehydrated and frozen tropical fruits-people who trade under the name of Sunmade. Their dilemma is this: for four years they have held an export licence and have been trying very hard to break into the export market. Finally, after four years of unrelenting effort they have succeeded in getting a small export contract to Japan on the promise that, if the goods are exported at a satisfactory price and in satisfactory condition-that is, satisfactory to the Japanese market-more orders will follow.

One can imagine that, after four years of effort, the people at Sunmade were ecstatic-until they found out on 21 September that there is a new range of inspection charges that will hit them called the fee-for-service, or FFS, charging system. The consequence is that there is a processing establishment charge of $530 per establishment; a charge of $59 per half hour or part thereof for inspection of the product in the field; plus an additional $5 per quarter hour or part thereof for all the paperwork that the officials have to do when they get back to the office.

Mrs van Slooten, who is one of the proprietors of Sunmade, advises that the quarantine inspection branch has told her that she should budget for a minimum inspection charge, for this very small order, of $1,000. That inspection charge will be equal to the profit that she is going to make on the whole deal. Her comment to me was, `Why should I bother trying to earn export dollars for this country; why should I bother spending years and years and years trying to get our produce overseas into new markets to pioneer the way, when, just at the point that I am so close to tapping into the market, the Government hits me across the face with new charges?'.

Mrs van Slooten was referring to the charge that was introduced on 21 September. In the long advice that was provided to her, she was told the charges were going to increase again on 1 January next year to bring them into line with what the Government believes is a reasonable amount to charge. The point that I make is that it is wholly unreasonable for the Government to mouth off at one time about how it believes it is important to have an export culture, and how it believes it is concerned with the level of export dollars earned-especially by primary producers-and, at another time, to impose arbitrary charges that are going to cripple many small Australian primary producer exporters. It is wholly inconsistent.

When one looks at the level of subsidies that farmers get overseas-levels of subsidies between 40 per cent and sometimes 60 per cent in the European Community and high levels of subsidies in the United States-I believe that this Government's penny-pinching, niggardly attitude towards primary producers shows that it has absolutely no interest at all.

I was surprised to read last week, for example, that Mr Brian Courtice, the chairman of the Prime Minister's country task force-the man who is charged with the obligation of advising the Prime Minister on the plight of rural Australia-had the audacity to say in the Australian Rural Times that he did not believe rural Australia was in crisis. He should tell that to the peanut farmers in Kingaroy, the cattlemen around Aramac or the woolgrowers around Roma and ask them what they say. They would say, I am sure, that Mr Courtice does not know what he is talking about, that this Government is badly advised and that it is selling the export capacity of this country short. That is the sad truth of this Government's policy.

It is said that when they bury a farmer in the United States they bury him only two feet down. The question is: Why do they bury him only two feet down? The answer is: So that even after he has died he can still hold his hand out. Australian primary producers do not ask for anything special. All they ask for is a fair go. All they ask is for a government to have a responsible attitude towards exchange rates and interest rates, and that is not too much to ask, because that is why people put governments in. All they ask is that when they finally come to win an export contract after four years of endeavour, they should not be slapped across the face by governments and bureaucrats who are just interested in raising a few extra dollars in charges.

The final irony of this very sad case of Sunmade dried fruits is this: Mrs van Slooten, the proprietor of Sunmade dried fruits, was in fact the woman who travelled to Canberra earlier this year to lecture departmental officials from the quarantine inspection branch on how to inspect dried tropical fruits. Instead of being congratulated on her effort and her contribution to the Australian export industry, what happens? The Government raises the inspection charges, so much so that this will be the one and only export from Sunmade dried fruits to Japan.

I can only wonder how many other small primary producers are in the same dilemma; how many other primary producers who currently hold an export licence, in the hope of one day breaking into the export market, will just cancel their licence altogether? That is my very real concern, and with it go the hopes and dreams of many of those 170,000 farm families across this country. For those reasons I believe that this Government stands condemned for neglect, a failure to understand, and a failure to care.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SERUM LABORATORIES (CONVERSION INTO PUBLIC COMPANY) BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 September, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That this Bill be now read a second time.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories (Conversion into Public Company) Bill 1990. The Opposition does not oppose the Bill, although I will be moving, on behalf of the Opposition, a second reading amendment later. The Bill amends the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Act 1961 to convert the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories-more commonly known as CSL-to a public company which is to be called Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Ltd. The Bill will also remove a variety of statutory controls which inhibit CSL's commercial operations.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill is said by the Government to be a major step in implementing the reform package for CSL which the Government announced on 16 August 1989 and which is part of the Government's comprehensive program, so it says, to improve the performance of government business enterprises. I might interpose in that context-I will come back to it later-that with very rare exceptions the best way of improving the performance of government business enterprises is to stop having those enterprises owned by government and, rather, let them be owned by the private sector in the way that most productive activity in Australia is conducted. That is an overriding consideration on the part of the Opposition and it is an essential part of Opposition policy.

CSL has a long history of achievements in serving the Australian community. In many ways it is a fine organisation. I know that there are differing views on the directions in which it has headed over the years, but it was established in 1916 as an arm of the quarantine service so that Australia could be self-sufficient in vaccines and sera in times of war and peace. Of course, 1916 was right in the middle of the First World War. In 1923, CSL was one of the four laboratories world-wide to produce insulin and, in 1944, CSL enabled Australia to be the first country to supply penicillin to its civilian population.

In 1952 CSL commenced the fractionation of serum provided by voluntary blood donors and collected by the Red Cross into life-saving blood products, a function which it continues to perform today. CSL has developed antisera and antivenoms against specific Australian pests and diseases, the most recent being the funnel-web spider antivenom in 1988. CSL is the only manufacturer of human vaccines in Australia and it is one of only two producers of biological veterinary products.

CSL became a statutory authority in 1961. At that time its charter focused on the performance of national interest functions, in particular the manufacture of prescribed biological pharmaceutical products and serum fractionation. Provision was also made at that time for limited commercial operations, using any excess manufacturing capability. At that stage, of course, it was just bringing the excess manufacturing capability into commercial operation rather than giving any specific priority to commercial operations per se.

As the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) said in his second reading speech, with support from successive Ministers of both major parties and successive governments, CSL has, since then, evolved into primarily a commercial organisation. Significant changes to the CSL Act by both the Fraser Government and the Hawke Government between 1980 and 1985 removed the restriction limiting CSL to manufacturing solely biological products and placed CSL's operations on a commercial profit-making basis. At the same time, CSL continued to perform some national interest activities for the Commonwealth under a reimbursement arrangement. Those changes to the Act also allowed the establishment of subsidiaries, joint ventures and partnerships. Nowadays, CSL markets a wide range of prescribed human pharmaceuticals and veterinary products both in Australia and overseas.

CSL is a very large operation. In fact, it is based, I am pleased to say, within a quarter of a kilometre of where I live in Melbourne. CSL currently employs over 1,200 staff and it has over 2,000 product lines. As such, it is the largest pharmaceutical company in Australia and it represents a unique pharmaceutical manufacturing capability. Most of those points were made by the Minister in his second reading speech. They are points with which I agree.

CSL has had some notable successes in recent times. It has won several export awards. Indeed, the future of CSL and the future of most manufacturing companies in Australia realistically must lie very importantly not only in the development of new products but also in looking outwards to new markets overseas as well as in Australia. In my view and in the Opposition's view that is one of the important reasons for the need to make CSL as commercialised, efficient and competitive as possible. That will happen only if the company is allowed to operate as a truly commercial enterprise that can respond quickly in the marketplace and is free from day to day regulatory controls.

The Government sees the reform package-to use its term-included in this Bill as a further significant step in the continued development of CSL. The Government says that the objective is to establish CSL as an efficient and commercially focused organisation able to compete profitably and effectively with the private sector in the domestic and international marketplaces.

The Opposition agrees very strongly with the objectives underlying this move to establish CSL as a company. What we are very disappointed about though is that this Bill represents only a halfway house. If the Government were really serious about giving CSL the resources and the wherewithal to develop and commercialise itself and become as profitable, efficient and competitive as possible in a highly competitive industry which operates in a highly competitive international environment, in our view it would not be adopting this halfway house proposal of turning the organisation into a company which still remains 100 per cent publicly owned. Rather, it would privatise the company immediately and expose it to competition and efficiency which is provided by private sector ownership. Experience has shown time and again this to be the only way in which most government business enterprises will have the wherewithal to find the capital, the expertise and all the other facilities that are needed for a company to operate successfully in today's world.

Fortunately, the Government saw the light in that respect with Australian Airlines Ltd at its recent special conference in Sydney. It was the only thing it did see the light on. It went a partial privatisation route with Qantas Airways Ltd by agreeing to a 49 per cent private stakeholding.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is only because it ran out of money.

—As my friend Senator Michael Baume said, and I am sure he will elaborate on this in his own remarks later in this debate, the only reason the Government did that was that it had run out of money to provide the necessary capital to Qantas to develop. That decision had nothing to do with a genuine desire by the Government to make Qantas an even more efficient and competitive operation. Of course-and I will come back to this if time permits-the so-called special conference in Sydney not only failed to move far enough--
—In Canberra.

—I thank the Minister. It not only failed to move far enough in relation to Qantas but it also failed abjectly in its attempt to bring greater competition in the private marketplace into the telecommunications industry when it voted to set up a 100 per cent mega-organisation-megacom; monstercom -by merging Telecom and OTC Ltd.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition regrets that the Government has refused to take the necessary step that would be required to put CSL onto the basis that it, and certainly the Opposition, believes is required. Therefore, on behalf of the Opposition, I move:
At end of motion, add `but the Senate is of the opinion that:
(a) Commonwealth Serum Laboratories should be fully privatised immediately; and
(b) there should be a full and complete divestment of all the Commonwealth interest and control in the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories rather than the half way measures proposed by this bill.'.

The fact that the Government is adopting only halfway measures and taking a halfway house approach to CSL at this stage will cause CSL some considerable difficulties. For example, as I understand it, CSL will still be limited in its capacity to have access to capital funds by the Government limit on global borrowing requirements determined under the Premiers Conference Loan Council requirements. That is a very significant inhibition on the ability of the organisation to find the necessary capital and funds for its development, particularly for the development of new products and research into new markets and the like which is so essential in this rapidly changing world of pharmaceuticals.

The fact that the Government is going only halfway, turning the organisation into a publicly owned company rather than a privately owned company, will not solve some of the essential problems of capital scarcity that CSL has.

There are other concerns which the Government has produced with this Bill and of which the Opposition is critical. For a start, the Bill has taken a long time coming into the Parliament. The announcement of these measures was made, as I said earlier, on 16 August 1989, but it took one whole year for the Bill to actually arrive in the Parliament. That, I must say, is indicative of the difficulty the Government seems to have in managing its affairs competently and efficiently.

This delay between the announcement of the decision initially and the introduction of the enabling legislation is typical of the delays that have been occurring in a whole host of areas. It is very unsettling, it is very debilitating, particularly for the organisations concern, because more often than not the legislation when it does see the light of day in Parliament is different in some respects, often very significant respects, from the details of the announcement initially made. So the Government delay in producing this Bill is a matter for concern, but it is, as I say, part of a general process of major difficulty which the Government seems to have in getting its act together in terms of the basics of management of government and of its affairs.

These delays cause great difficulties for business enterprises because they feel uncertain about their future. If one were one of the 1,200 employees of CSL and waited for 12 months between the time of an announcement that the organisation was to be converted into a company and the time of actually seeing the details of what was involved, one would know that that is not conducive to good morale, and not therefore conducive to effective personnel management or to the operation of the enterprise itself. As well, of course, those delays make it more difficult to meet some of the commercial activities which the organisation is supposed to be carrying out.

It seems to me crazy for an expert charged with running a commercial enterprise to have to fix up a strategic corporate plan, as was the case in this instance, and then to have to come to Canberra to seek approval from the Minister. If one is really serious about letting CSL go the way that the marketplace and other demands require, one cannot subject the development of strategic corporate plans to the dictates and whims of Ministers.

The coalition amendment is designed to obviate these problems. It is designed to enable the organisation to immediately be floated or sold, whichever way would be dictated by commercial prudence and normal practices, to the public so that the people of Australia can become shareholders in this important organisation.

I hope that the Minister in summing up this debate will respond to my request for information and comment as to why the Government will not take the final step and let CSL enter the marketplace-let the shares that are being held by the Government be offered in part to staff, if they wish to take them up, which is an essential part of a privatisation exercise, and let the shares in what is demonstrably a successful and important government business enterprise go to the wider community. What are the reasons for the Government failing at this stage to take that important step, and why does the Government want to hold on to its ownership of CSL? I think that they are important questions and I hope that the Minister in responding to this debate will address them.

The Bill does not come anywhere near the goals of privatisation. The Government says that it wants to encourage value-added manufacturing within Australia without the requirement for underpinning by the Commonwealth, yet underpinning is precisely what will occur with this Bill. If the Government cannot make a decision about CSL-important though it is, it is one of the smaller government business enterprises-how will it ever be able to make a decision about the more vital areas that require privatisation among the realm of government business enterprises?

The answer, sadly, is that the Government will not be able to take those decisions. The Government has shown that in many respects it is the total captive of a very conservative movement in Australia in relation to the release from ownership by the public sector, namely, the trade union movement. That was the whole basis for the Government tearing itself to bits over the really minor matter, when it came to the question of privatisation and competition, of telecommunications. It could hardly get to first base in taking sensible, rational decisions there because the trade union movement and other vested interests within the Labor family prevented it from doing so.

Therefore, we are saddled with a situation where in the case of telecommunications we now have no hope in the long foreseeable future of getting the competition, the increased efficiency and private sector involvement in telecommunications that are so essential. Regrettably, the same will be the case with most other government business enterprises. One can see it happening a mile off. That is regrettable because it means that this Government, because it is the captive of vested interests that are absolutely opposed to the private sector and to private enterprise for a whole host of ideological and other reasons, is therefore preventing Australia using its resources in the most efficient way possible.

We face a situation in Australia today where the economic problems confronting us are the most serious certainly since the end of the Second World War, and quite arguably the most serious since the great Depressions of the early 1930s and the 1890s. The fundamental difference though between the problems that confront us today and the problems that faced us on those two previous deep recession occasions was that previously the problems were imposed upon us by international collapse. Today the problems that we have in this nation are totally determined by the problems occasioned by the policies of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are no international difficulties at all-that is what you are trying to say, is it not?

—Senator Cook says mockingly that there are no international determinations of our problems. That is very largely right, with the exception of parts of the rural sector in recent times. But those opposite have been in government during 7 1/2 years of unprecedented growth in world trade and the Western world economies and the developing world economies. The Government has not faced any problems imposed from outside in the whole period it has been in government. Despite that, it has managed this country into the greatest set of economic problems that we have had in at least half a century. That is a pretty difficult thing to do. This Government has done it very successfully, but the cost to the nation, the cost to future generations of Australians, is overwhelming.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to the Government that, unless it changes its whole approach to the operation of business undertakings now publicly owned, and unless it is prepared to let go the apron strings and allow those businesses to have private ownership, private capital involvement and the ability to tap the world market free of constraints of governments, then the problems that are presently compounding in this nation will get progressively worse. Of all the differences between the Government and the Opposition in terms of their approaches to the future of this nation, I can think of no starker contrast between the two major parties than in their approach to the question of privatisation.

The Opposition has a full-blooded and publicly announced program of privatisation. We have that because it is essential if we are to increase competition; it will lead to services for consumers which are cheaper, more efficient and provide a freedom of choice; and it is a program of management and use of resources in Australia which will lead to a dynamic, progressive, growing economy rather than the stultified economy that the public ownership of so many of our resources is at least in part contributing to.

Our privatisation program will increase efficiency and competition wherever possible, and that will be on most occasions. We will give employees the opportunity to buy shares on a preferential basis-something that is totally precluded in this Bill. It is not permitted because, of course, there is going to be no divestment of shares to other than government ownership. We believe that employee share ownership provides a common interest in an enterprise for employees and employers, and an incentive to improve productivity. I can only express again the concern of the Opposition at the inability of the Government-for whatever reason but it is essentially due to it being captive to vested interests-to see the need for a full privatisation program and to act accordingly.

Having said that, I return to my earlier comment that the Opposition does not oppose this Bill to establish the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories as a company. It is a worthwhile development. The point that we would make is that it is only a halfway house development and, whilst not opposing the Bill, we will be moving an amendment-as I have already intimated and as has been circulated in the chamber-to call on the Government fully and immediately to privatise CSL.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing this afternoon the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories (Conversion into Public Company) Bill 1990, which seeks to corporatise, but not go as far as Senator Short would and privatise, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories (CSL). Speaking as I am immediately after Senator Short, I cannot fail but remark on how incredibly blind members of the Opposition are when on the one hand they totally reject the evidence right before them and argue for privatisation, competition and efficiency and, on the other hand, argue that everything the Government owns is uncompetitive, is inefficient and does not produce those things which are in the best interests of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: We have before us an organisation which was started in 1916 and which has been in total government ownership for 74 years. It has served this country extremely well and, indeed, in 1988-89 it made a profit of $11.8m. It paid, as far as my estimates show, $6 2/3m to government by way of tax and a 40 per cent dividend, yet Senator Short says that that organisation is inefficient and needs to be privatised. The other week the Bond organisation lost $4,000m. That is a totally private organisation which is supremely efficient at one thing-at losing money which has been contributed by Australians, which adds very considerably to Australia's foreign debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are no successful companies, are there! What about BHP?
—What about Elders IXL? Tell us about that.

—I thank the Minister for the example. Elders IXL has also lost thousands of millions of dollars. There is no necessary nexus whatsoever between whether an organisation is government or privately owned and between efficiency and serving the public interest. There are government-owned organisations, such as CSL, which have functioned very well for 74 years, have been efficient and have returned a profit, and there are, of course, government organisations that have not been efficient. But equally there have been private organisations which have been grossly inefficient and have certainly not served the best interests of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: There is nothing magical whatsoever about privatisation, and we would certainly express great fear that the Government has gone part of the way towards privatisation. My colleague Senator Spindler will be moving an amendment to this Bill which will seek to prevent that further stage of development from corporatisation to privatisation for precisely the reverse reasons which Senator Short elaborated on in his speech. We would strongly urge the Government to support the amendment which Senator Spindler will be moving, because Senator Short has put on notice the fact that, if the coalition should form the next government, one of the first things it will do, having got this far with the privatisation of CSL, is move to privatise CSL fully.

Senator Spindler's amendment, if put in place, will make it mandatory that that next step of selling shares to non-government people or organisations must come back into this Parliament and be made on a decision of the Parliament, not merely by the government of the day. Unless the Government has on a secret agenda the privatisation of CSL-and that may well be on its agenda- we would strongly urge it to support Senator Spindler's amendment.

Let me elaborate further on that point. Senator Short and many people in the coalition when speaking on the privatisation of other organisations have referred to the people of Australia owning the companies that are privatised. Surely the best way that every person in Australia can own an organisation, can own the operation of that organisation, and can have some say in the output-the sorts of products which are made and the sorts of end uses to which those products are put-is through government ownership. Then every Australian will have some share in the ownership of that property.

It is a matter of fact that only 7 per cent to 10 per cent of Australians ever own shares; 90 per cent to 93 per cent of Australians never own a share during their lifetime. I guess it is a mark of the failure of this Government to increase equity in this country that it is now in a position of having to privatise those things which all Australians own-in other words, to sell them off to no more, and certainly in many cases considerably less, than 7 per cent to 10 per cent of the Australian public. In other words, from 7 per cent to 10 per cent of the Australian public evidently now have the wealth accumulated under this Labor Government to buy that which Australians as a whole can no longer afford to own. That process, quite clearly, would be exacerbated were we to have a coalition government.

One of the other two points I wish to make-I do not wish to speak at length on this Bill-is that health is one of those areas which does not fit well with privatisation, with competition and with being driven by the profit motive. CSL is an organisation par excellence which has developed unusual products, products which might only be used to treat a small number of patients but whose conditions if left untreated would prove fatal. For example, a small number of people in Australia are bitten and envenomed by various dangerous creatures in this country. Therefore, a small number of people benefit very considerably from the development of antivenenes by CSL.

That is the sort of development which is not likely to be undertaken by a company which is profit driven. A company that is profit driven is far more interested in manufacturing a product used by a large number of people and by which it can maximise its profit. It is not particularly interested in manufacturing something which may well be lifesaving but will be used by only a small number of people and from which there is very little profit. CSL has been a world leader in developing some of those antivenenes. Being an Australian company, it has developed antivenenes against many of the spiders, snakes and other creatures which we have in this country. The development of those antivenenes is not something that is likely to be undertaken by companies overseas.

The other point I would like to make briefly is that it is vitally necessary that Australia maintain a considerable public interest in the pharmaceutical industry. If this organisation is to be privatised -clearly we have heard from the Opposition that that is its direction if it forms a government-the next step will be rationalisation of the industry and we will see certain products manufactured in Australia and others going off-shore and manufactured elsewhere. Before too long we could well find that the substantially foreign ownership of CSL would come to dominate even more the Australian pharmaceutical manufacturing industry and we would finish up with a very small indigenous pharmaceutical industry. We would not only lose those very important products to which I have already referred but we would also lose a handle on the cost structures which operate in this industry.

This is an industry where, with certain products, vast profits can be made. Just as the sale of the Commonwealth Oil Refinery (COR), for instance, by the Menzies Government in the 1950s denied successive Australian governments a handle on the cost structures in the oil industry and have left us now in a situation in which we are totally dependent upon whatever figures the industry wants to provide to government, the loss of a handle on the pharmaceutical industry through CSL would produce a similar condition in which we would be left entirely at the mercy of the very large multinational pharmaceutical companies which operate throughout the world and which could provide any figures they wanted on the cost of production, research and so on. We would have no indication whatsoever from our own operations under the control of our own government as to the exact costs.

It is simply untrue, given the figures before us on the profitability of CSL, that CSL is not capable of providing the funds necessary for research and development. As I have already indicated, in 1988-89 CSL made a $11.5m profit-a 9 per cent profit on sales. That compares very well with most privately run companies in this country. A 9 per cent profit on sales is very good. CSL was able to pay a 40 per cent dividend after tax to the Government. The Government's revenue increased by $6.67m in one year as a consequence of CSL's operation. Given that we are talking about the health area, given that we are talking about an industry that should be run for the benefit of Australians and not just as a profit making venture, it would seem to me that within that scale of profit on its turnover, there is plenty of money for the research and development which CSL should be carrying out.

To summarise: we are not opposing this Bill but we express grave concern that, as Senator Short has correctly identified, it moves part of the way towards privatisation. We are concerned that, given that and given the clear statement from the Opposition, should the Opposition form the next government, CSL will be privatised. The consequences of that we believe will be damaging to the health of Australia because those very small scale and unusual but sometimes lifesaving products will no longer be manufactured, as they will no longer be profitable, and because we will be likely to lose the control of a sufficient part of the pharmaceutical industry, with the result that we will not be able to understand the detailed financial operations of the industry and, therefore, keep some sort of necessary handle on it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always with a sense of unreality that one follows the Australian Democrats in debates such as this. The objection to the Opposition's plans to privatise the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories (CSL) is, in Senator Coulter's mind, based on the view that there is no such thing as a successful Australian public company. We did not hear either the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) or Senator Coulter mention one company that has any kind of successful record. The only examples of Australian corporate activity that the honourable senator could think of in this context were those of Mr Bond.
—And Mr Elliott.

—And Mr Elliott. I am intrigued at the quality of intellectual activity that goes on in that corner when a debate on a serious matter such as this rests on such a fragile base. SPEECH.PARA: We did not hear anything of that from Senator Coulter because that is an intrusive fact that does not fit in with his philosophical prejudices. The fact is that this is a commercial body; it behaves in a commercial way. The latest annual report-and this is a fairly late annual report; I will deal with that matter shortly-says this:
Unfortunately, the Government decision on the future of CSL was still awaited at year end . . .
This is the annual report for the year to June 1989. It continues:

The task of retaining experienced managers and recruiting new ones remains an acute problem under conditions of salary restraint and uncertainty over the future. Meanwhile, change in the industry continues apace.

I want to deal with a couple of matters of how unfortunate this half-way house approach really is. One of the major things the Bill does is to remove this body from the scrutiny that, frankly, all bodies should be subject to-the scrutiny of its shareholders. At the moment the shareholders of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories are the people of Australia through this Parliament. Honourable senators have the opportunity at Senate Estimates committee hearings to inquire of this organisation, through the people who run it, how it is accounting to us for its management.

One of the consequences of what will happen when this legislation is passed-we will be supporting it-is that by getting into this half-way house we will no longer have effective access to the management of this body, to ask it the sort of questions that any management deserves to be asked. There is not going to be an annual general meeting of this corporatised body, as there would if it were privatised, which the shareholders can attend. It is going to report to the Minister, but let us see how effectively this body has been reporting to the Minister so far. While I strongly commend the activities of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories in its scientific area, I do not extend that to its speed in reporting to this Parliament.

Quite frankly, if CSL reported as late to the stock exchanges as it has to this Parliament, it would be de-listed. Maybe that is one good reason why we are not privatising it. But it ought to smarten itself up. I have here the Auditor's report in the latest annual report for the year ended 30 June 1989. The Auditor's report is dated 29 November 1989. The Chairman's report to the Minister is dated 1 December 1989-almost five months after the end of the financial year. It is not good enough. CSL will have to do better. Maybe in a more competitive environment it will be enthused to do better. If CSL was privatised, it would be forced to do better.

One other matter worth mentioning in passing is that because Parliament did not sit for quite a while then, we did not get the report until well into the year. There is a touch of unreality trying to deal with an annual report from a body with a very substantial turnover-$130m-so late after the end of its financial year. When the Auditor-General dealt with the accounts, he disagreed to an extent with them on a question which I believe is worth raising in the Senate, and it is the question of whether accumulated sick leave is a right to employees. The Auditor-General clearly does not believe so and says on these accounts:

Provision for employees benefits: This provision includes an amount of $2.3m in respect of sick leave. The amount is reflected in the Balance Sheet partly as a current and partly as a non-current liability . . . As it has not been satisfactorily demonstrated that a liability for sick leave actually existed as of 30 June 1989, the Australian National Audit Office considers that the amount should not be represented as a provision. Had the Commission shared this view, the operating profit before income tax would have been increased by $2.3m . . . Tax Benefits and Retained Profits Carried Forward are each overstated by an estimated $1.8m after tax.

I mention that in passing because it strikes me as extraordinary that in some areas if people do not take sick leave because they were not sick, they still appear to be entitled to accumulated sick leave. I thought this was a safety net to protect people, not some sort of right to take away. The problem we face here is a very simple one in that the half-way house which removes this body from proper supervision is one that should and must be passed through as quickly as possible. The reason I stress this is that there has been some correspondence on this kind of issue. For example, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) wrote to one of the Senate Estimates committees to say:

The Senate's former Deputy President and Chairman of Committees, Senator David Hamer, and the Clerk of the Senate, Harry Evans, are both of the view that the Estimates Committees have before them only the estimates and unless there is an actual appropriation of moneys to such bodies in the estimates being considered, statutory bodies are not open to examination during these hearings.

The same applies, of course, to corporatised statutory bodies. To make certain that this situation exists, I notice that the Minister suggests that the community service functions of CSL-as I said, 4 per cent of its activities relate to community service-would be made more efficient and accountable by a formal contractual arrangement with the Commonwealth. The Opposition has no problems with that concept because if it were a privatised body, that would be the appropriate way to deal with its small proportion of activity that relates to the public sector. We believe all of these functions would work better under that system. But the Minister's plan is clearly to avoid direct government funding of the new CSL, so it is removed totally off budget.

We get no opportunity of pursuing matters on behalf of its shareholders, the Australian people, at Senate Estimates. I find that to be intolerable at a time when there is no other effective opportunity for the shareholders to ask tough questions. It is all very well to say that the Minister is maintaining control, and certainly he is. I must say that some of the aspects of the Minister's control seem to me to be quite curious, particularly when the Minister is going to retain the right to interfere strongly with the running of CSL while at the same time being on the other side of deals that CSL is supposed to make independently and on a commercial basis with the Commonwealth.

So the Minister will be on both sides of the deals that CSL is to make, or at least will have the capacity to be on both sides of the deals. It seems to me that we have a situation where there is to be less capacity for the shareholders, the people of Australia, to supervise how this body is going and to ask the appropriate questions than there is even now, and I am really concerned about this. However, it would be wrong of me to sit down without having said something very positive about CSL itself. Having criticised its late accounting and its obvious disagreement with the Auditor-General, I want to reinforce the views expressed here earlier about how it has behaved in an adventurous and progressive way in what is, and has been described as, an illustrious career.

CSL has been associated with a number of major advances in therapeutics. It developed a whole range of antisera and antivenenes against specific Australian pests, the most recent being the funnel-web spider antivenene of 1988. Having said that, there is no doubt that the lack of government capital, for example, has been some sort of a constraint on its activities to do more, although I ought to mention that at the moment it is expanding rapidly. I think there is $30m to be spent in the current estimates on construction of blood fractionising facilities. Even though this was delayed last year, the construction phase of the project is now under way.

There is no doubt that CSL's ability to develop new products has lagged, and one would hope that privatisation, which will take place under a coalition government, will give it greater opportunities in that area. It is only through product innovation, and in particular perhaps alliances with strong international companies in this area, that a good, strong future will be assured. I should mention, in passing, that CSL is virtually the only source in Australia of active ingredients for pharmaceuticals.

This is a body which has done remarkably well. It is a body with a very proud history. It is an organisation that will be able to do even better privatised once the shackles of governmental control and governmental constraint are removed from it. All I can say to the Australian Democrats is that if it is their intention, after we win the next election, to block legislation to privatise bodies like this, I suggest that they should on all occasions make that a very public statement and let the people of Australia know that, no matter what kind of mandate we get at the next election to correct the structural mess that this country is in as a result of this Government's policies, the Australian Democrats are going to ignore that mandate and block our legislation.

If that is their intention, let them be honest enough to say so here and now, and I will look forward to the next contribution from the Australian Democrats to see whether they have the stomach for that kind of activity. In the meantime, I strongly support Senator Short's amendment, that the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories should be fully privatised immediately and that there should be a full and complete divestment of all the Commonwealth interest and control in the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories rather than the halfway measures proposed by this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill before the Senate, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories (Conversion into Public Company) Bill 1990, has been introduced as part of an alleged reform. I suggest that `reform' is indeed the wrong word. The words perhaps should be `reconstruction package for Commonwealth Serum Laboratories', announced in August 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill amends the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Act 1961, to convert the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories into a public company called the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Ltd. Whilst I welcome this move because it will remove a variety of statutory controls which have actually inhibited CSL's commercial operations my support is actually tempered by the failure of the Australian Labor Party Government to move to full privatisation of CSL, as suggested by my Liberal colleagues, led by Senator Short and Senator Michael Baume.

The privatisation formula for CSL, as per this Bill, is for CSL to be registered as a normal company with all of its shares, however, owned by the Commonwealth and the Minister having the power to give directions. I have a misgiving in relation to shares to be issued by a nominee of the Commonwealth because it is in this area that we have seen so much trouble in relation to some of the entrepreneurs, and I would have thought that that would have been unnecessary in the Commonwealth's case.

In August 1989 the Government recognised that CSL ought to be far more commercial. CSL, with many other government business enterprises, was having difficulty in maintaining its market share. As with other government business enterprises, it was calling upon the Government for additional capital and it was felt, quite rightly, that those enterprises ought to be made far more commercial and there ought to be more line management capacity within those organisations. That is partly why this Bill has been introduced.

I believe it is a matter of some regret that the Government has taken only half a step-that is, corporatisation-towards freeing up CSL so that it can vigorously, or more vigorously, pursue market opportunities in the pharmaceutical industry, not just domestically but also internationally.

Others have already made mention of the contribution CSL has made since it was established in 1916. I wish to draw to the attention of honourable senators some of the more recent achievements of CSL, as noted in its newsletter for August and September 1990. For example, CSL's diagnostic division has scored a major export coup in Japan with one of its key products. It has successfully negotiated a distribution agreement for foetal calf serum with the Japanese company, Toyobo.

Japan is one of the largest world markets for foetal calf serum, an essential growth factor used in cell culture. Sales from the initial three-year contract with the Japanese company will be worth significantly more than CSL's total Australian market for that particular serum. It took 18 months of hard work, including four visits to Japan, to secure this particular agreement.
The establishment of this contract with Japan indicates the potential which exists for the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Ltd in its corporatised form.

I commend the August-September CSL newsletter to all senators. It contains an article entitled 'Building a Great CSL' which covers the corporate, divisional and research and development objectives of the soon to be corporatised CSL. In the words of CSL's Managing Director, Dr= Brian McNamee:
The package is designed to enable CSL to operate on a more commercial basis and to become competitive and profitable in its own right.
How much more commercial it could have been were it to be fully privatised really begs the question.

In order to achieve these commercial objectives, CSL is now adopting a new strategic direction based on three fundamental requirements: first, to significantly improve its operational performance; secondly, to develop improved biological products for human use; and, thirdly, to seek strategic alliance between partners as a means of gaining access to new products, technology and export markets. These requirements raise serious questions. Why were these not priorities beforehand? Why has it taken a notion of corporatisation to try to improve its operational performance in the past? This is surely a reflection on the management in the past.

Within this context of change, the Government has specified three key objectives for CSL: first, to maintain an Australian manufacturing base for biological pharmaceutical products-a laudable objective; secondly, to preserve our current system for supplying critical blood products; and, thirdly, to operate without government subsidy. I ask the question: will there be further calls on the Commonwealth for funds? Investment of $30m is required, as was outlined by Senator Michael Baume.

The corporate strategy which has been developed by CSL is consistent with the Government's key objectives and recognises the need for profound change based on: first, reorienting CSL to its origins and core strengths as a human biological company; secondly, maintaining CSL's corporate independence while establishing strategic alliances-the Joint Committee on Public Accounts recommended that while there be at least a cent of Commonwealth moneys in these sorts of corporatised operations, the Commonwealth Auditor-General, the Australian National Audit Office, should be the final auditor for such a company; and, thirdly, investing in new manufacturing facilities and research and development to make its products more competitive on international markets. In Dr McNamee's words:

Our new strategic plan not only provides the best opportunity to create substantial value for our shareholder but also ensures CSL's long term viability as an internationally competitive Australian manufacturer.

We on this side of the House wish it well. CSL has, as its motto or its catchcry, 'putting quality first'. I would not like to think that, in passing this Bill today, which goes only halfway towards full privatisation of CSL, we were jeopardising that motto. (Quorum formed)

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate and those honourable senators who have contributed to the debate on this most important Bill, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories (Conversion into Public Company) Bill 1990, which relates to converting the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories (CSL) into a public company.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, as honourable senators will know, was established in 1916 and has had-`a long and somewhat chequered history' would be too strong a phrase-times when it has performed extremely well. The initial impetus for its formation was to ensure that Australians could be self-sufficient in vaccines and various sera in times of war and crisis and then, of course, in times of peace. Certainly, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories has tried to fulfil that initial impetus and charter over the succeeding decades and, indeed, generations.

It is quite clear that the modern trend is to secure the further development of CSL by putting it on a more commercial footing and by allowing it to be subjected to the usual planning and accountability mechanisms that one associates with corporations rather than with previous structures within government. I believe that, with the provision of a corporate plan and the formation of strategies to achieve the goals set in that corporate plan, we will see the benefits of this transformation.

The National Companies and Securities Commission, or, as it will now be, the Australian Securities Commission, will be the repository of the memorandum and articles of association of the CSL public company. Of course, the shareholder-in this case, the Commonwealth-will be in a position similar to that of other shareholders in any public company. That will enable the Minister responsible to exercise that sort of influence over the CSL which is desirable in such a key institution in the provision of various vaccines and other preparations so vital to the health and well-being of Australians. In so far as it has an export potential which is being realised, we are talking about not only a community service to Australians but also a capacity to benefit people who are overseas and who have a commercial arrangement with CSL in order to have the benefit of the scientific expertise and research and development of the various vaccines and other special preparations which are the specialty of CSL.

This Bill is rather complex in parts. This is because this transition will need to be effected in various stages to ensure that the CSL continues as a legal entity, and to enable it to have its taxation position and other matters properly adjusted and dealt with during the transition period. I believe that there is general support in the chamber for this package of legislation, except that the Opposition, of course, would wish the Commonwealth Government to go much further and bring about the immediate privatisation of CSL.

The Government, quite properly, has indicated that it cannot support the privatisation of such a key institution, upon which the health and well-being of so many Australians is quite utterly dependent. I think that most Australians would wish to retain their status as shareholders effectively in this particular institution, mediated, of course, through the Government, which will have the rights of shareholders in relation to the operation of the company. I believe that that is something which most Australians would support. For that reason, the Government would not be willing to accept the second reading amendment moved by the Opposition. Therefore, I commend to the Senate the second reading as proposed by the Government.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Extradition Amendment Bill 1990 and the Opposition is generally supportive of this Bill. We have a couple of concerns which I will deal with, but we will support the legislation. Clearly, we support a modern extradition system for this country and recognise the fact that efforts in recent years have been made to negotiate new bilateral extradition treaties or extradition arrangements with a number of countries. I understand the Government is claiming that such arrangements have now been negotiated with 26 countries and another 14 are in various stages of negotiation. We are pleased with that because we are all aware of instances where inadequate extradition laws have not only been embarrassing to this country but have allowed criminals to escape justice, and that is destructive of our democratic system.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill amends the Extradition Act which we passed through this place only two years ago, so I guess I have to say at the outset that we are somewhat disappointed that the Government has found it needs finetuning within such a short period of legislating the principal Act. It reminds me that on many occasions in recent times we have had to draw to the Government's attention deficiencies in its legislation. We call upon the Government to put in the effort that is necessary to produce quality drafting and quality legislation in order that such subsequent amendments are kept to a minimum. Nevertheless, we accept that technical finetuning, as has been described by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson), is now required in this area, and this Bill provides such adjustments.

I indicated that there were some areas in which we had concern. We dealt with them in the other place. In fact, in the other place we were planning several amendments until we received certain assurances from the Government. Our areas of concern principally relate to clause 4, concerning the application of the Act, and clauses 6 and 8, dealing with the presumption against bail. Clause 4 amends section 11 of the principal Act. It alters the regulation-making power under the Act to give effect to Australia's international obligations concerning extradition. Section 11 provides that regulations may be made to give effect to Australia's extradition relationships by applying the Act to `specified' extradition countries, so that Australia will then be able to extradite to those countries.

Australia's extradition obligations come from a number of sources, including bilateral and multilateral treaties and non-treaty based arrangements. It is often the case that our obligations will stem from a combination of these sources. But because of the way in which section 11 is presently drafted, the Act cannot apply to a country by more than one of these means-that is, only one of the sources can be recognised. Thus, if a recent multilateral treaty has an impact on Australia's obligations under an existing bilateral treaty, regulations under section 11 cannot identify, and give legal effect to, this latter source.

Clause 4 of the Bill is intended to remedy this defect, to ensure that the regulations made under section 11 accurately reflect Australia's extradition obligations as they may be altered from time to time. We have argued that this clause is poorly drafted and we called upon the Government to improve the drafting. We regret that the Government has not done so. We were of a mind to seek to assist the Government in that regard; however, there were a number of consequential amendments that would follow and it really seemed, therefore, somewhat inappropriate. Nevertheless, we draw this deficiency to the Government's attention, as is our responsibility, and we hope it works as the Government claims it will and it is not another short period time before we are back here with the Government producing more necessary finetuning amendments in this regard.

Clauses 6 and 8 of the Bill extend the presumption against bail in the principal Act to situations involving the review of extradition decisions. Under sections 15(6) and 32(3) of the Act, when a person is arrested, pending the decision of a magistrate to extradite, there is a presumption that the person will be remanded in custody. Bail will not be granted `unless there are special circumstances justifying such remand'-a phrase which is not defined in the legislation. This presumption, which, of course, reverses the usual situation which we find under State law where there is a presumption in favour of bail, is said to be necessary to address concerns on the part of some nations about Australia's ability to fulfil its extradition obligations. The suggested amendments propose the extension of this presumption to situations where extradition decisions are being reviewed or appealed. We note that the Government has not seen fit to offer any reasons for the extension of this presumption.

Nevertheless, we are prepared to concede that it may be desirable that there be a presumption against bail in the context of an arrest or an appeal initiated by the person avoiding extradition. However, we would seriously question the desirability of such a presumption in the context of an appeal or review initiated by the country seeking extradition. After all, a court would have already made a decision at first instance that the person is not eligible for extradition or surrender. The courts, under the existing provisions of the Act, already have a discretion to grant bail or to remand in custody. That discretion is exercised after considering the seriousness of the alleged offence, the character and history of the person involved, and the strength of evidence against the person. The court can then refuse bail if the granting of bail would be an unacceptable risk.

The Opposition is therefore of the view that the amendments proposed in clauses 6 and 8 are unnecessary. However, as I said earlier, we are not going to pursue amendments because of the assurances given by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) in the other place that if a case for extradition has not been made out in the first instance, the Government is of the opinion that that would constitute special circumstances justifying a remand on bail during the appeal process.

Therefore, in such circumstances, we have considered that our proposed amendments are unnecessary. We nevertheless trust that what the Government has put to us in fact is that which is appreciated by the court to justify special circumstances, and we will only find that out when this matter is put into practice.

Therefore, although we have a couple of reservations, we are not proposing now to move amendments. As I said at the outset, overall we support a modern, capable extradition system for this country. We think it is part of the necessary international mechanisms that are now necessary to fight particularly organised crime, and we are therefore pleased to facilitate the early passage of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My comments on the Extradition Amendment Bill will be brief. The Democrats support the legislation but we also have some concerns, which I will outline. The Bill seeks to make a number of changes to the provisions of the existing Act which, briefly, will allow regulations to be made to facilitate action under both bilateral and multilateral extradition treaties. In the normal course of events, extradition arises pursuant to a bilateral or multilateral treaty and under international law, no rights to extradition are recognised, apart from those rights specified in treaties or other similar international arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: The second reading speech of the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) indicates that the Government has formed a task force to negotiate modern bilateral extradition treaties or extradition arrangements, and this is pleasing because it is an effective crime control approach which is necessarily transnational in nature, and appropriate extradition arrangements are an essential part of that.

I will now turn to some of the details of the Bill. The main provision of the Bill, clause 4, will amend section 11 of the principal Act, and its effect will be to ensure that regulations made under section 11 accurately reflect Australia's extradition obligations as they may be altered from time to time. A new section 33a will be inserted into part 3 of the principal Act by clause 7, and this provision will streamline the procedure governing situations where a person consents to be surrendered to New Zealand.

Clauses 6 and 8 deal with the presumption against bail. Under the Act, when a person is arrested pending the decision of a magistrate and relating to the extradition, there is a presumption that the person be remanded in custody and not be granted bail unless special circumstances are shown. Clauses 6 and 8 propose the extension of this presumption to situations where extradition decisions are being reviewed or appealed.

Finally, I turn to clause 10 of the Bill and put on record some concerns the Australian Democrats have about it. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee raised this clause with the Minister, and I quote from the Chairman's letter about it:

As you will be aware, the clause proposes to insert into the Extradition Act 1988 a provision which would allow police officers, in certain circumstances, to arrest without warrant a person released on bail.

In normal circumstances, the Democrats would be extremely concerned about persisting with legislation, without seeking to amend it, which gives police the power to arrest a person without a warrant. However, we have taken note of the answer that has been provided by the Attorney-General, which states quite clearly the circumstances that have led to this particular clause and identified the difficulty which police officers would face in a situation where a person who breaks bail conditions must be presumed to be well on the way to extricate himself or herself from a situation which would mean certain extradition to a country which could deal with his or her criminal transgressions.

We accept that once a person has had a warrant issued against him or her the presumption must be that there is a reasonable cause why he or she should be extradited. While we continue to have concerns about this provision, we accept that in practical terms it is a provision which, for the time being and subject to future monitoring, will be supported. It is always difficult in these circumstances to weigh up the often conflicting principles of the protection of civil rights and the need to protect the community from crime and, while we are taking the position I have outlined, the Democrats will be monitoring this situation closely in the future to ensure that abuses of civil rights do not occur in the name of crime fighting. Apart from that concern, we are pleased to add our support to a further strengthening of the powers available to deal with criminal activity in the international arena.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: — I thank those senators who have contributed to the debate on the Extradition Amendment Bill. It so happens that at Question Time today I was able to indicate to the Senate that internationally Australia is held in very high regard as far as its extradition treaties are concerned and the general way in which it has undertaken very vigorously in the international community to enter into cooperative arrangements, to ensure that there is no safe haven for criminals moving from one jurisdiction to another in order to escape the claims of justice in regard to the criminal transgressions they may have been involved in, as Senator Spindler would put it. Of course, in relation to mutual assistance in criminal matters, we also have a series of treaties which again have been adopted by the United Nations conference in Cuba as models for the world community. In fact, both types of treaties have been forwarded to the United Nations General Assembly for its separate consideration because the conference in Cuba thought that it was so important that this be done.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, in relation to legislation underpinning such arrangements there can be occasions where matters domestically manifest themselves which require some clarification. I think basically that is what is being undertaken, certainly in regard to section 11 of the Act. At the moment, as has been remarked upon, it is not possible to list in regulations all countries to which Australia can extradite for crimes created pursuant to multilateral treaties, such as the hijacking convention and the convention for the protection of protected persons.

I would not want to give the impression that the regulations do not presently provide for giving effect to multilateral extradition treaties, but what the amendment does is permit the regulations, very clearly on their face, to reveal to the public exactly what offences render a person liable to extradition to which countries, and that is the key. We wanted the Act and the regulations to be as clear as possible. We think obviously it is in the interests of those who may find themselves caught up in this process, and their legal advisers, but there is also obviously a general public interest in these matters being as transparent as possible. The amendments to section 11 are, I think, uncontentious and I believe that that is why they have secured such ready support around the chamber.

What has also been raised by senators as a matter of concern is those provisions which will give police power to arrest without warrant a person who is about to abscond, and that is what we are trying to tackle in relation to these matters outlined in clause 10 of the Bill. I believe that these are important provisions and I undertook to the Minister to indicate that it is true that Senator Cooney, on behalf of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, sent a letter to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), and I quote:
While it has not formally drawn the Senate's attention to the clause on this occasion, the Committee would be interested to receive your advice as to the rationale behind the provision.

That letter is dated 20 September 1980 and is signed by Barney Cooney as Chairman of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. The Attorney-General has replied. It might be of use to those who are interested in these matters if I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the reply from the Attorney-General so that it is there as a supplement to the explanatory memorandum in relation to this matter.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Senator Barney Cooney
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee for the
Scrutiny of Bills
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Cooney
EXTRADITION AMENDMENT BILL 1990

I refer to your letter of 20 September 1990 concerning clause 10 of the Bill. Your Committee seeks the rationale for this provision which would allow police officers, in certain circumstances, to arrest without warrant a person released on bail under the Extradition Act 1988.

The amendment is designed to minimize the chances a person released on bail under the Extradition Act has of escaping the jurisdiction of the court. Currently police officers have to obtain warrants where they suspect the person has or is about to contravene a bail condition.

For example, presently a police officer cannot arrest a person without warrant even if the person is about to board a plane at an airport and the police officer knows that the person was released on bail under the Extradition Act and that by boarding the plane (or even being at the airport) the person would be breaching a condition of his or her bail. Of course, by the time the officer could obtain the warrant the person would no doubt have left Australia. The proposed amendment will enable arrest to occur in these circumstances.

You will, of course, be aware that the courts have held that State bail laws do not apply in extradition cases because the Commonwealth has evinced a legislative intention to cover this field. The proposed provision enacts a Commonwealth law which is consistent with State bail laws such as s.24 (1) Bail Act 1977 (Vic); s.50 (1) Bail Act 1978 (NSW); s.54 (2)(a) Bail Act 1982 (WA); s.18 (2) Bail Act 1985 (SA); s.35 (6) Justice Act 1959 (Tas); s.29 (1) Bail Act 1980-1982 (Qld); s.38 (1) Bail Act 1982 (NT) and ss.347, 358AI and 352 (2) Crimes Act 1900 (NSW) As amended in its application in the A.C.T by Laws of the Territory.
Yours sincerely
MICHAEL DUFFY

As to Senator Hill's point about perhaps considering making different presumptions applicable, depending on whether it is the person who is sought or the extraditing country which is making an appeal, I am advised that this would be extremely difficult, given the possibility of conflicting presumptions where there is an appeal by the fugitive and a cross-appeal by the requesting country in cases where there are multiple offences. I am advised that this situation has occurred from time to time. So it would be extremely difficult to try to present the court with a decision to make on the basis of, as I say, what could be conflicting presumptions.

I thank the Senate for its obvious support for this improvement to the extradition legislation passed by this Parliament a couple of years ago. I understand the concern expressed by the Opposition and by Senator Spindler in that we must create a situation where in our zeal in fighting organised crime, particularly that which has an international dimension, we do not sacrifice the rights which are properly recognised as inhering in persons who are subject to police investigation and then prosecution in our court processes. We hope that we maintain that balance as well as possible, given the objective of ensuring that we have international arrangements in place which allow our cooperative effort with other jurisdictions to try to stem organised criminal activity spilling over the various borders, particularly when it has to do with drug trafficking, but not exclusively confined to that particularly heinous activity. I thank the Senate for its support and commend the second reading of this Bill.
