TALK.START.PARA: —The Defence Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 deals with a number of Bills within the Defence portfolio. It proposes to amend the legislation covered in it in the following ways. It amends the Defence Act and the Naval Defence Act to remove restrictions on the Chief of the Defence Force's power to make single service command appointments. It removes some redundant positions dealing with seniority. It modifies provisions relating to enlistment of soldiers and sailors to enable the open-ended enlistment scheme to operate more effectively. It makes an amendment to the Defence Force Discipline Act to replace obsolete references to the offence of rape with references in the current Australian Capital Territory provisions that have replaced the former offence of rape. It amends the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act (No. 1) 1985 to remove an unnecessary provision relating to allotments. It seeks to amend the Defence Force retirement and death benefits legislation to increase the orphans benefit. It also proposes to amend several Acts to replace references to the Joint Intelligence Organisation (JIO) with references to the Defence Intelligence Organisation. In other words, it amends the name of that organisation from JIO, as it is better known, to the Defence Intelligence Organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is entirely in support of these amendments. I suppose of greatest interest is the proposed amendment to the Defence Force retirement and death benefits legislation to increase the fixed component of the orphans benefit from $702 to $5,000. The Opposition has been calling for this amendment for some time. However, several other amendments are important. The Opposition would not want the entire consideration of this Bill to be devoted to the increase in the orphans benefit, although I want to say some more words about that.

The new command structure for the Defence Force-the role of the Chief of the Defence Force as the overall commander of that Force and direct command established between him and the land, maritime and air commanders-is an important new development. There were some statutory inhibitions to fully effecting that new structure in the Defence Act. I do not know why that was not dealt with earlier. It was discovered to be a problem because appointments still had to be made by the Chief of the Defence Force through the Chiefs of Staff. That is proposed to be changed. It is entirely appropriate that that be the case.

As to the open-ended enlistment scheme, there seem to have been some strange delays in getting this legislation onto a proper footing. I do not know why that should be the case. The policy was decided upon several years ago. The first attempt to implement it was in 1987, I think. The full legislative provision for the scheme is now in place. Instead of enlisting for a fixed period, one can now enlist until retirement age; not for life, of course, but for the period of years that soldiers and sailors serve. It provides for that to be done with the ability to give appropriate notice, statutorily fixed at 12 months, although that can be varied in certain cases.

However, the purpose of this legislation is to provide that a soldier or sailor who has enlisted until retirement age does not have a right to claim a discharge during the first six years of service or, again, for such period as his relevant Chief of Staff determines. The legislation lays down some criteria which will govern the determination of the Chief of General Staff, which is only appropriate; namely:
(a) the ability of the Army to carry out its current and possible future military operations; and
(b) the size, and composition, of the Army; and
(c) the training of the Army.
Obviously these are all considerations which are highly relevant to the question of whether there should be a commitment to serve for a period of six years or for a lesser period than six years.

This legislation will fully implement the open-ended enlistment scheme, or the legislation relating to it. As I said, I simply do not understand why it has been done in two bites. It seems extraordinary that there would have to be two attempts at statutory changes in order to implement a new scheme.

As I said, the Opposition is particularly pleased to find the increase in the orphan's benefit. However, that benefit has not been increased for 18 years. The reason why there is this striking difference, between $700 and $5,000, is that it has just never been indexed. The legislation, which increases it to $5,000, does not provide for any indexation. The explanation that the Government has given for the absence of indexation-although that was, in fact, recommended by the Cross committee on personnel wastage-was that it will fix it up when it brings in the legislation to give effect to the new Defence Force retirement benefits scheme, known as the military superannuation and benefits scheme.

The indexation of the $5,000 will be provided in that legislation. Why on earth it could not have been done in this legislation is beyond my understanding. We have already seen the messing around with the different statutory attempts to implement the open-ended enlistment scheme. I hope that Defence will be able to smarten up a bit and produce legislation as it intends it to be, instead of having these various bites at the cherry.

My colleague Senator Newman, who has the principal responsibility for the Opposition in relation to this aspect of the legislation, has raised these matters with the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mr Bilney, and has obtained that assurance from him. She was also rightly concerned about the position of the sailors who are serving and others who, no doubt, will be serving in the Gulf, and the present deployment there. She was particularly concerned about the position, if any of the sailors were killed, of their widows. Under the present Defence Force retirement benefits scheme, the widows are entitled to a pension, but under the new scheme, which is yet to be legislated for, they would be entitled to a lump sum. However, I am pleased to note that the Minister has written to my colleague Senator Newman. He has given an assurance, the terms of which I will read into the Hansard, because it is very important. Mr Bilney states:

Let me assure you, that it is my intention that in the event of the death of any ADF member serving in the Gulf, the equivalent to the lump sum option proposed for a spouse in the DFRDB Review would be applied by the Government.

The Opposition's enthusiasm for this legislation is based, to some extent at least, on commitments which Senator Newman has obtained from the Minister in the course of correspondence since this legislation has been introduced. It is a less than satisfactory situation, but that is the way this Government goes about things and the way this legislation has been presented to us despite those reservations. As I said, the Opposition supports the measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the provisions of the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill as far as they go. However, we feel that there is one other urgent amendment to the Defence Act which it would be timely to deal with now. I must apologise to the Senate for not having circulated this amendment earlier, but I will be moving it in the committee stage of the Bill. As the President said earlier today, I expect that we should actually be able to conclude consideration today.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Democrats' amendment is to ensure that Australian troops cannot be sent overseas to fight or to act as peacekeepers without the agreement of both Houses of Federal Parliament. This provision is one which already applies in other countries and one which would in this country at least allow a full debate and a vote in both Houses of Parliament before our young men and women were sent to fight in a foreign country. Obviously, it is a timely one.

In the situation in which the world currently finds itself, we are constantly being told somewhere in the media, almost daily, that war in the Middle East is imminent. I profoundly hope that that is not the case. I believe that a peaceful solution is still possible through negotiation, and I am encouraged by the involvement of the United Nations (UN). I believe that stronger involvement by that body is desirable and probable. However, the possibility still exists that Australia will be drawn into a war in the Middle East against our wishes. In that case the Democrats believe that it is in the best interests of the Government, and especially of the people of Australia, that every one of their Federal elected representatives should be involved in the decision whether or not to send troops to such a war.

I will just describe the amendment briefly so that we can go through the committee stage a little more speedily. Basically, section 50c of the Defence Act 1903 requires Australian military forces to serve overseas. It contains no provisions at all limiting the right of our Prime Minister to send troops overseas at any time that he or she would wish. Our amendment would make it necessary to get the agreement of both Houses of Parliament before troops could be sent overseas to war or even as part of a peacekeeping force. This provision applies in other countries.

In Canada, the Governor-in-Council may deploy troops anywhere, at any time, subject to Parliament meeting within 10 days to approve that action being taken. In Germany, even a united Germany, there are still limitations. At the end of World War II the allies made constitutional provisions prohibiting German forces from participating in a war of aggression. Even a peacekeeping role is prohibited unless in response to an illegal attack on Germany itself. Article 9 of the Japanese Constitution states:
The Japanese people forever renounce war as a sovereign right of the nation.

The Japanese have, until now, refused to participate in UN peacekeeping forces because of their Constitution. Of course, feeling in that country at the moment is running very high over the issue of sending troops to the Gulf in order to protect Japan against indirect aggression. There will be a debate and a vote in the Japanese Parliament on the issue very soon.

Our amendment seeks to place the responsibility for a decision to send Australian troops abroad with this Federal Parliament, subject to exceptions covering the movements of personnel in the normal course of their activities and the need to take fast action in an emergency. Parliamentary approval for any emergency deployment of troops would need to be obtained within two days of the dispatch of those troops.

The amendment also contains important exclusions. It excludes overseas service by members of the Defence Force pursuant to temporary attachment as part of an Australian diplomatic or consular mission; on an Australian vessel or aircraft not engaged in hostilities, or operations during which hostilities are likely to occur; for the purpose of education or training; or for purposes related to the procurement of equipment or stores.

This amendment is designed to reinforce the idea that the power delegated from the people of Australia is not given to one man or woman but to a group of men and women known as the Federal Parliament. It should be the decision of members of this Parliament, as the representatives of every Australian, whether or not to send any Australian troops overseas.

The obvious example of a disastrous decision to send Australian troops overseas is, of course, Vietnam. One of the most divisive issues in Australia's history, it involved some 50,000 service men and women, many of whom are still paying the price for that decision now, 20 years later. Nearly 500 of our troops were killed in that war and nearly 3,000 were injured. All this was as a consequence of a decision to involve Australia in a war with no proper consultation of the Parliament or the people.

For many years we were told that Australians fought in Vietnam in response to a plea for help from the Government of South Vietnam. That is rubbish, obviously. Australia was involved in that war because the United States did not want to be seen to be acting alone. That sort of shameful incident should never be allowed to happen again in this country. We believe that our proposed amendment would be the most effective way to achieve that aim.

SPEECH.PARA: I will make the comment-which I am sure Senator Bourne will accept-that we are currently dealing with an omnibus Bill that relates to a number of certainly important matters, but none of which approach the magnitude of the amendment which the Australian Democrats are hoping to simply tack onto this omnibus Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is of the same view as the Government in relation to this amendment. We will oppose it. We have a longstanding position in relation to this issue. Of course, it is not a new issue. I am not sure whether the Australian Democrats have, in fact, advanced it before in this chamber but I have a suspicion--
—Yes, we have.
—Yes, Senator Powell is indicating they have. I think this chamber has already debated the matter and, if my memory serves me correctly, I have been involved in that debate in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of whether our defence forces should be required to serve overseas has been traditionally determined, under our Constitution, by the Executive of government. Decisions of executives of governments have been made over the years in a cautious way, and there does not appear to have been a case of conflict between the Parliament and the Executive in relation to this question except, maybe, in relation to Vietnam. But I remind Senator Bourne that, in relation to Vietnam, the conflict emerged far down the track.

My very strong view is that the Parliament would have very strongly supported the decision to deploy Australian forces in that country, in the first place. The objections to it came much later. Nothing in this legislation would have affected that position, because there is no power of recall by Parliament in this amendment. I do not think it would have been of any benefit whatever to Senator Bourne or the Democrats in that case.

Australian members of the defence forces may also be required to serve overseas in many capacities. I notice that a clause in the Bill does not require the approval of Parliament in a number of limited situations, but those situations are particularly limited. There would be many occasions when Australian members of the forces may be deployed outside Australia in situations which are very far short of war. In particular, I refer to peacekeeping forces.

My guess is that with a renewed United Nations interest, and agreement within that body, Australia will be called upon more often in future than probably has been the case in the past to provide peacekeeping forces. There are many occasions when this could arise and when it would be quite surprising if Parliament had to approve of that deployment. The Opposition believes that, essentially, these decisions are ones to be made by the executive arm of government, and there is no demonstrated requirement for Parliament to assume this power to itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator POWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment briefly on what I understood to be the response of the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) to the proposition that the amendment should be supported. I have to agree with him that it is a proposition that does deserve considerable and considered debate in this chamber, and indeed in both chambers of this Parliament, and I can see no impediment to such a debate here tonight. Even if there were, I think it is a particularly appropriate time, as Senator Bourne has said, for the matter to come before us again. I stress 'again'. It is a matter which has been raised in the past by the Australian Democrats. Indeed, if there were not time to consider it, we ought to be making time.

SPEECH.PARA: The concern that we have is not a concern solely of the Australian Democrats in this chamber; it is a concern expressed to us in the community increasingly as days go by and the situation in the Middle East becomes more and more precarious. As we scan through the Australian Associated Press print-outs even tonight, following statements out of the United States about the inevitability of armed conflict escalating in the Middle East, it must be a matter of serious concern to us all.

What people are saying to me and to many of my colleagues is that they are concerned that, as with world wars I and II in which this country has been engaged in the past, in a sense we seem to be being conditioned to reach a point where we will be sending our armed forces into an engagement which is indeed a war; that we are now in a situation of the phoney war which will turn into the real war at any time. I hope that is not the case, as I am sure we all do, but there is concern in the community. Given that this is our policy and that we have attempted this before, people are responding positively, certainly to me and to my colleagues, when we say that we believe no such decision should be made unless the Parliament is involved in debating such a proposition.

It is very disappointing that on neither the Government side nor the Opposition side does there seem to be a willingness to do that. We as representatives of the community believe we do have a role if we are to send young Australians overseas with the great potential of losing their lives, particularly when there is time to consider such potential deployment and certainly when tonight there is time for us to consider the proposition that we might do that. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wholeheartedly endorse the amendment moved by Senator Bourne in the committee stage of the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill. I appreciate the sentiments behind it and the substance of the amendment. It is very important that on a crucial issue such as service of the Australian defence forces overseas, the Parliament be consulted. I know that this issue has come before the Parliament before. Of course, it is highly pertinent now with the hasty decision of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to send Australian troops to the Gulf region without consultation with Parliament, indeed without consultation with Caucus, and with very limited consultation with a carefully selected group of his own Ministers. It is deplorable when so much power is vested in one person. I have said repeatedly that it was a bad decision which should be reversed. The Prime Minister should have consulted more widely.

SPEECH.PARA: It may have happened in this situation that the consent of both chambers of the Parliament would have been given, but the point remains that Parliament was not consulted. The people of Australia felt that they had no decision-making input to this rash and hasty proclamation of the Prime Minister that ships would go to the Gulf in support of the American position. I think history may show it to have been a decidedly unwise decision. I believe it to be so now, whatever transpires in the next few months. I hope that it does not spark into a full-blown conflict in the Gulf region. The principle remains as strong; it is a consistent position that the Parliament of Australia should be consulted, that it should not be up to the executive members of the Parliament, and the Prime Minister himself, to decide under what circumstances Australian troops should be deployed to overseas engagements.

It was only a few months ago at the seventy-fifth anniversary, or commemoration-I think that is a better word-of the Gallipoli debacle that the Prime Minister said with tears in his eyes that never again would young Australians be serving in a foreign shore and never again would the situation develop where young Australians were sent off to be like lambs to the slaughter. Yet when it is convenient to him and his own political agenda to be seen to be supporting the Americans with such undue haste, he commits young Australians to a potential war zone much more dangerous than anything that was experienced with great pain by those forefathers of the Australian defence forces on the Gallipoli slaughter field. There is another potential slaughter field coming up. The principle is that the Parliament and the people of Australia should have some input into such an important decision.

Therefore, it is very important that the Australian Democrats' amendment be supported. I am not surprised that the Government and the Opposition have said that they are not interested. They are not very interested in democracy. What they are more interested in doing is supporting the American line. They do so consistently. Our Prime Minister especially is extraordinary in his support of the American position on almost every issue and I do not think that the Opposition would be much different. It has not given us any indication that it would be very different in supporting the American position. It was an American position that was supported, not the United Nations position-which I would have endorsed.

There is a great deal of support in the Australian community for the United Nations position but not for the militarisation that was engineered by the United States Government. It is that which most people are objecting to and it is that which could still explode literally into the most devastating circumstances known to humanity with chemical, biological and nuclear weapons all ready to go in the Gulf and our Prime Minister, on the whim of a phone call to President Bush, saying, 'Okay, let's go'. In fact, he committed five ships and the Navy had to tell him with some embarrassment that we did not have five ships to go. So keen was he to be supporting the American position.

It is very important that this principle be enshrined in Australian legislation: that the Parliament of Australia be consulted, that the people's representatives in this place have a chance to put their views, that Australian troops are not deployed in any overseas engagements without the permission of the Parliament. The same situation could have arisen in the past few years on various other occasions when the former Minister for Defence was very keen to give the Australian defence forces some overseas practice with their new gadgetry that he so willingly acquired on their behalf. Mr Beazley had the troops ready to go to Fiji, Vanuatu and Papua New Guinea. Again, those matters should have come before the Parliament. A decision must be made with the consent of the elected representatives of the Australian people. This is the place where a decision should be made to deploy or not to deploy Australian forces overseas.

My position on this matter is well-known. I do not believe that the Australian forces have any business in being deployed overseas under any circumstances whatsoever. I would support what Senator Bourne said in her opening remarks: that negotiation and a mediated settlement is the way out of this dispute and the way out of all disputes. I wholeheartedly support the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: But regrettable as we all find it, there are individuals and people in this world who do rise to positions of great power, who have the potential of inflicting great human misery on the people around them and who do not find it easy to be persuaded by logic, reason or negotiation. As I said at the beginning of this debate-and I will conclude on this point-many countries, including democracies such as our own, have had major debates on the role that executive government and parliament, by whatever name we call them, play in this fundamental question of how we deploy troops in times of emergency or war and, particularly, overseas service. Executive governments are ultimately accountable to parliament, one way or the other, in a democracy such as our own. TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating an omnibus Bill, the Administrative Services Legislation Amendment Bill 1990, which will amend or repeal a number of Acts falling within the Administrative Services portfolio. As the Bill relates to a diverse range of legislation within the portfolio, I will consider each amendment separately. The first amendment is to the Archives Act 1983. The Australian Archives is responsible for all records generated by the Commonwealth agency since Federation. Its purpose is to ensure consistent and accountable management of Commonwealth records in the interest of efficiency, effectiveness and equity. It makes available to members of the public information on the structure, location, functions and records of existing and previous Commonwealth government agencies.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1988-89 the Archives handled 17,230 public inquiries, an indication of the enormity of its task being 315,100 shelf metres of files at last count. In recent years the entire Department of Administrative Services has moved towards the introduction of user charging for services, either on a full cost recovery basis or at commercially competitive rates, where market rates are available. In 1988-89 the Archives raised a total of $139,000 in revenue compared with a total expenditure of $17,870,000.

The purpose of this amendment, as I understand it, is to allow the Director-General of Archives to determine in writing charges for discretionary services provided to Commonwealth agencies. Previously any levy of charges by Archives for any of its services was to be prescribed by regulation in accordance with section 71 of the Archives Act.

This amendment provides the Archives with flexibility to determine charges in accordance with market conditions, and is a means of putting the Archives on a business basis-a sense of direction which the Opposition supports-and a means of imposing economic disciplines on other government agencies. I think this is a move in the right direction, because it enables for the first time some sort of real cost to be put on the services provided by a government department. It makes those people who would normally think there was no cost to these things think twice before asking for frivolous information.

The only comment I would make is that I have some concern, although I agree with the sense of direction, about the whole business of trust accounts. One of the problems with trust accounts is that, curiously, statutory corporations are more accountable to the Parliament than are trust accounts. It is something I think this Parliament will have to address down the track. The Opposition will not oppose that amendment.

The second amendment is the repeal of the Naval Properties Act 1925. This legislation is now redundant as a result of the New South Wales Government in 1985 granting an easement in gross which protects the Commonwealth's maritime rights. It provides for ratifying agreements between the Commonwealth and New South Wales for the transfer of Cockatoo and Snapper islands from the New South Wales Government, and part of Goat Island from the Commonwealth. For that reason we will be supporting that amendment.

I turn to the repeal of the Procurement of Goods, Works and Services Act 1981. This Act, of course, is now redundant. It provided for a 20 per cent discount of Australian tenders to give preference to Australian producers. In 1989, it was announced that the scheme would be phased out and a non-discriminatory policy introduced. This Act has been overtaken by a series of purchasing reforms and new preference arrangements which have applied since 1 November 1989.

I now refer to the amendment of the Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 1) 1930 and the Social Security Act 1947. The 1987-88 Budget announced the proposed sale of the Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Services Ltd. That company was sold on 1 July 1988. These Acts are amended to remove reference to the Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Services which, of course, is no longer a Commonwealth instrumentality. Therefore, that amendment will also be supported by the Opposition.

The amendment to the Parliamentary Allowances Act, however, is something to which I wish to address myself. I foreshadow at this stage an amendment in the committee stage of the Bill. The Bill provides for continuing payment of additional allowances to office-holders other than Ministers from the date of dissolution of either House, or of the Parliament, until polling day where they are to be candidates for election. It has arisen, I understand, as a result of representations made several years ago from the Clerks of both Houses to the Minister seeking legislation to fix payment of additional salary for those office-holders who have parliamentary duties during the term of an election campaign. I stress that: during the term of an election campaign.

The present system of ex gratia payments which had to be approved by the Minister for Finance was considered to be cumbersome from the point of view of estimates and vulnerable as a point of law. However, I point out that it appears it was not intended by the parliamentary officers that the allowance would be extended beyond those who received an ex gratia payment in 1987.

On 10 March 1989, the President of the Senate, Senator Sibraa, and the then Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mrs Child, wrote a letter to the then Minister for Administrative Services, Mr West, in which they pointed out that the Parliamentary Allowances Act 1952 provided for the continuation of salary payments to members of both Houses from the date of dissolution of the House of Representatives, or both Houses, until polling day, where those members are candidates for election.

Payments to Ministers continued pursuant to the Ministers of State Act 1952. Section 6 of the Parliamentary Allowances Act makes special provision for the continuity of payments or allowances in respect of the officer of the President of the Senate, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, the Chairman of Committees of the Senate, and the Chairman of Committees of the House of Representatives.

However, because there was no provision for allowances known as additional salary and expenses of office to be paid to other office-holders, the President and the Speaker recommended that legislation be changed to cover a certain group of people. Those people included, for instance, the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, the Leader of the third party in the House of Representatives if there was one, the Leader of a recognised non-government party of at least five members not otherwise specified, and the Whips.

What has happened with this particular amendment is that the Government has extended that recommendation from the President and the then Speaker to cover a whole range of people. I think it is worth while going through that list. Apart from those people to whom I have just referred, it also includes the Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts; the Chairman of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works; the Chairman of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade; the Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters; the Chairman of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority; the Chairman of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation; the Chairman of the Senate Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committee on Community Affairs; the Chairman of the Senate Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training; the Chairman of the Senate Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts; the Chairman of the Senate Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration; the Chairman of the Senate Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade; the Chairman of the Senate Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology; the Chairman of the Senate Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committee on Infrastructure; the Chairman of the Senate Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs; and the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs.

I just make the point that this is for the period from when an election has been called until polling day. This legislation wants to give the additional allowances for all these groups of people in that period of time. The list goes on as follows: the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs; the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts; the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training; the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration; the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology; the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communication and Infrastructure; the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs; the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure; and the chairman of a parliamentary committee not otherwise specified herein-just in case a few more are collected along the way.

If this Government is serious about engaging in micro-economic reform, it has to start with itself and the principle of no work, no pay should apply. If the Government will not give a lead in these matters, what hope is there for the rest of Australia? The Government cannot ask people to tighten their belts while it continues to hand out largesse to its own parliamentarians at a time when there is no way in the world that those parliamentarians will be doing the work for which they are paid, unless-and I make this point-they think that at the time, because an election is on, there are some political Brownie points in doing so.

I have heard arguments in the other place that a certain honourable member felt that during the election campaign he had to answer a few questions by telephone to staff engaged in Canberra about a report that came down in January. I ask: Is that justification for paying this vast range of people who in no way in the world will be involved in any of those committees during an election campaign?

The dollar amount involved is not big. My own back of the envelope calculation indicated that it was about $32,000. That may not seem much, but there is one hell of a principle involved. I think the question has to be asked: Do these people carry out those duties when there is an election on? I am pleased to see that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator McMullan, is on duty tonight, because with his background, he would know that more than anyone.

As I mentioned earlier, the Opposition in the committee stage of this Bill will move an amendment, the effect of which will be to cover those people who were not covered previously but who carry out their particular duties from the calling of an election until polling day.

The effect of that would be that those people would continue to get those payments even though there is no way in the world they would be doing the work for which they were paid. This, in itself, is a reflection on the Government, which keeps talking about improving efficiency, improving productivity and saving taxpayers' money, while at the same time, when the Government gets an opportunity to keep handing out taxpayers' money to its own people, it cannot resist it. What a lead to give to the people of this country: tighten your belts; things are tough; the recession is on; we must do something about changing the attitudes of this country. TALK.START.PARA: — I rise to say that the Australian Democrats support the Opposition's amendments to this legislation for the reason that Senator Parer has outlined. SPEECH.PARA: I must confess to some slight embarrassment at having the carriage of this legislation for the Australian Democrats. However, perhaps I could declare a pecuniary interest and be excused for having this portfolio on this occasion; I could not persuade anyone else to come here and do it for me. SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose in a sense it is easier for me than for most other people to speak in defence of the Government's position on this matter because for those extra responsibilities which I have over and above the ordinary responsibilities of a back bench member of Parliament, the salary is zero, so whether this motion is carried or not, it will not make the slightest difference to me.
—It is the same with all my shadow Ministers.

—I will swap them jobs. So that is fairly easy for me. I think everybody in this chamber would appreciate-I have been waiting to hear it mentioned, and I have been surprised it has not been mentioned-that the most difficult time for any member of parliament to be asked to perform any activity outside his electorate is during election time. It is arduous for members from remote areas at any time to come to Canberra for committee meetings, and we put terrible demands upon them. But at election time, for a member in a marginal seat to be diverted in any way from the fundamental election campaign activity is a very high price to pay.

SPEECH.PARA: I appreciate that the Opposition and the Australian Democrats are expressing proper concern about the defence of taxpayers' money, and we all do that because we realise that in the decisions we make here to spend money, we are spending other people's money, and we ought therefore to be very concerned about the circumstances under which we do it. But there are two essential elements to the argument that have not been explored. I will not take the time to reiterate those that have been stated in other places and to which I referred in the second reading debate.

First, in those matters that were referred to, for example, in the House of Representatives, the present Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) had been the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology during the course of the election, and he was able to recount those activities which he undertook; they were not as onerous as the activities which he would have undertaken at other times but they were being undertaken at the most difficult time. Honourable senators who have had such responsibilities have not appreciated calls being made upon their most valuable time, and there is no more difficult time in which to carry out those non-essential activities. The continuation of those activities, even at a lesser rate, is a function that ought not to be ignored. As campaign director for my Party in previous elections, I have been annoyed to find members not available to do the jobs that I thought were the most important because they were performing duties which they had been called upon to do by the Parliament.

Secondly, we need to remember that the amount of payment that members receive is not a weekly amount. It is not the same as a fitter in the railway workshops who is paid a weekly amount. Members receive an annual allowance which takes into account the times when the committee is sitting, and the times when the committee is not sitting. If the committee does not have a current reference, payment is not stopped. If Parliament is not sitting, payment is not stopped to the whips. It is an annual amount to compensate them for the discharge of their obligations over a three-year cycle. If there was something which said that a member was paid weekly, then for a week when a member was not discharging the obligation, it may be possible to argue that the member ought not be paid for that week. Members of parliament do not get annual leave as such, but other people who are paid salary are not discharging their obligations when they go on annual leave, and we do not stop paying them because that is part of the assessed annual obligation of the worker to the employer. I believe it is an analogous situation. There is proper concern about taxpayers' money but it is misconceived in this instance. I urge both the Opposition and the Australian Democrats to reconsider their position on the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question I asked the Minister on duty was this: What justification did the Government have to deviate, to the extent it did, from the request made to the then Minister for Administrative Services, Mr West, in the letter from the President (Senator Sibraa) and the Speaker, Mrs Child, on 10 March 1989? TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take this opportunity to make a few comments about our recent delegation to Moscow and Leningrad, from which I have just returned. The Soviet Women's Committee invited a cross-parliamentary group of women politicians from the Australian Federal Parliament to visit the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, and I was one of the people fortunate enough to be able to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to pre-empt any official report that the delegation may give, but I want to make some comments in the nature of first impressions before those impressions get lost. They may not be for the benefit of everybody else, but I certainly would like to have the opportunity to make these comments now so as to remember in particular a number of things from the visit that I regard as particularly important.

First of all, I would like to thank the Soviet Women's Committee for its splendid hospitality, for its organisational skills, for providing interpreter services, for arranging our travel within the Soviet Union, for organising any number of meetings and for seeing to our accommodation-all of which was done with great ability and a minimum of disruption or trouble. I think the Soviet Women's Committee is one group that certainly gets done what it says it will do, and I want to offer my thanks to it. Also, I would like to thank our Australian Embassy staff in Moscow who, of course, provided assistance, briefing information and support to the delegation in its time in Moscow.

For the record, I would like to thank those women who were interpreters for us-Elena, Galina, Vera and Tania in particular-and also those people who worked as guides for us. I said before I went that I thought we were very privileged to be going to the Soviet Union at this time. It is, I suppose, a great privilege to be there at such changing times.

From outside of the Soviet Union it looks very exciting. Certainly the movement to peace and the bringing down of that Wall that closed eastern Europe and the Soviet Union to the West is something that I think has pleased people all around the world, not only because the threat of war is receding-nuclear war, in particular-but also because that part of the world that was fairly much closed to the rest of us is now available and open.

Curiosity being what it is, many people wanted to go and have a look. But, more importantly, many people wanted to take the opportunity to make contact with people behind the Iron Curtain and in the Eastern bloc, particularly those who have friends, family and relatives in this country or in other countries in the Western world.

I would like to put on record in the Senate tonight some of my impressions. First of all, these are very exciting times for us. They certainly are changing times for people whom we met in the Soviet Union. They are also very frightening. The women told us again and again that they had a faint optimism and a great anxiety. I suppose that is a fair assessment or summary of what they said.

They are very pleased, of course, to acknowledge President Gorbachev's contribution to peace, but they appreciate, too, that the last five years have seen their standard of living worsen dramatically. So it is hard to know how, on balance, that works out for them. Many of the women would not want to blame Gorbachev, but they do not want to speak favourably of him. They also do not feel that it is likely that he will be overturned, but some of that, they would agree, may be in the nature of hopeful thinking, if not wishful thinking. There seemed to be little evidence of that while we were there, but I have to say that we did not peer into every corner.

These are challenging times, very exciting times and very concerning times. The standard of living, we were told, is much worse than five years ago. Another thing that struck me was the war-weariness of the Soviet Union. Certainly the recent Afghanistan venture is to the front of people's minds, but in Leningrad we were able to visit the monument to the siege of Leningrad, the stand of that city against the siege by the Germans for 900 days between 1941 and 1944 in the Second World War.

Most of Leningrad was turned into rubble. It lost its water and power very early on during that siege. The population of over three million people in Leningrad at the start of the siege was reduced by 1.2 million. Those people died mainly in the first year of the siege from starvation and the effects of winter when they did not have any heating. Still, the people in Leningrad held out, and we know the course of that piece of history.

People are very uneasy about the prospects of more war. They are very weary and tired, and they are certainly very concerned about the potential for further loss of life. While the quality of life may be a cause of concern, they would rather have that than the prospect of death. We were told it is estimated that some 40 million Soviets have died or been killed since the Revolution. That is a fairly extravagant way to care for a population.

People welcome peace, but that peace is associated with the changes of perestroika and glasnost and the Soviet people told us that they are very concerned that things are no better-indeed, they would say worse. The old order has changed but the new one is not defined and not in place. Food shortages have not been as bad since 1947. The women who work all day-and something like 91 per cent of women in the Soviet Union are in the work place; 51 per cent of the work force is female-then have to stand for many hours in queues for what food is available.

Food and consumer goods are both in very short supply, and what is of concern at the moment is that the food shortages are now going to the very basic commodities such as bread, butter, eggs and potatoes. We were told that plenty of food had been produced this season but the problems were twofold. One was harvesting the crops and the second was transporting it, particularly to cities or population centres like Moscow and Leningrad. It certainly did not seem as though these problems were going to be solved in the short term.

The shortages continue, people queue for long hours, they do not see any way that things are going to change, and they just know that they are getting very tired. I also think that we have to make sure that we do not place Australian values on life in the Soviet Union. We have to appreciate the differences. That means that we should not so much be critical as interested to be informed and be prepared to offer information rather than judgment or moral values.

We visited work places and found there that the workers were provided with such things as laundry facilities, a seamstress who would either mend or make clothes for a modest fee, a hairdresser, manicurist, sport and recreational facilities.

In one place there was an arrangement with a nearby swimming pool. Of course, child-care was provided either on site or nearby. Indeed, some of the workplace enterprises provided food for workers to buy, which sometimes reduced the time they had to queue. Those services are very unusual and not like what women in the Australian workplace would find, at least in the large part. The services may be there, but the buildings, the structures and the facilities are very tired and very out-of-date. Still, one acknowledges that considerable contribution.

We were also shocked at the salaries. But again, the salaries paid to people need to be qualified by the outlays. For example, a teacher would earn 110 roubles a month. We divide this by five to get a rough conversion into Australian dollars. We gasp when we see what it amounts to. However, for about one Australian cent people can ride the metro underground all day. Telephone calls cost about 2c. The cost structures need to be balanced against that income. In particular, we were advised-though I do not know that I can claim this to be the case in every situation-that the rental a person pays for living space is pegged at about a maximum of 10 per cent of income. These qualifications need to be added.

One of the interpreters who travelled with us to Leningrad was interested when I asked her whether she wanted to move to Leningrad or work there. She said, `I cannot'. I asked her why and she said, `Because it is stamped in my passport'. She showed me her passport. It stated that she was entitled to five square metres of living space in Moscow. Her passport said that that was her entitlement. Five square metres is not a large space. That certainly pulled me up very short. Her husband has an entitlement and her family has a small entitlement for children. But the majority of families in Moscow would live in two rooms, apart from a bathroom and a kitchen. They do not live extravagantly in terms of housing space.

The only way she could move to Leningrad was if she found someone who wanted to do an equal exchange or if her husband's work took him to Leningrad, in which case her passport and accommodation would be changed. I believe that those restrictions on space are put there not so much to punish people or to set limits, but rather to keep people out of Moscow; to stop a massive migration into the large centres. I have not been able to authenticate that piece of information.

The other problem that really shocked us was that very little safe or reliable contraception is available to women in the Soviet Union. We understand that about 5 per cent of Soviet women could have regular access to reliable contraception. We were also told that very many Soviet women could expect to have 10 to 12 abortions in their fertile lifetime. Of course, this is because abortion is the only contraception for them to fall back on.

After listing those impressions, we could be left with the idea that all in the Soviet Union is gloom and doom. I would certainly like to qualify that. The women of the Soviet Union showed energy, courage and warmth. Their hospitality is legendary. We certainly experienced that welcome and hospitality.

The other thing that struck me was the hunger of those Soviet women for the information we could provide. While we were there trying to find out what it was like for the Soviet women, asking them to tell us the facts and figures in their country, they were busy asking us what information we could bring. We had a splendid exchange of information.

I was very struck by this hunger for information. That was part of the welcome. The attitude was, `Do come. We are so pleased to get a source of new information; new ideas that might contribute to our thinking; new ways to look at the formulation of women's policy, for example'. They asked how we had done it in our country, who formulates the women's policy and what it covers.

They were particularly interested to ask us how we got elected. In their recent elections, the quota system for women was not in place. I never got the opportunity to ask, `Who took away the quota? Why was it judged that the quota should go?'. But the quota did go. So the number of women in the Soviet Parliament is very much less. Both men and women preferred not to vote for women candidates. The Soviet Women's Committee has some hard work ahead of it. It has to examine the reasons why, and particularly look at ways in which women can be more successful when campaigning in future elections.

They were very interested to know how we in Australia campaigned. Amongst other things, we told them that one puts out bits of paper with one's photograph, one's policies or one's Party's policies. They then said that there was a shortage of paper and also a terrible shortage of printing ink in the country. I suppose one thinks about fixing the supply of printing ink before one thinks about campaigning with bits of paper. The shortage of paper and printing ink is a chronic problem in terms of the production of printed information of all sorts, particularly books and publications which we in this country would regard as the norm. There is a considerable shortage of those. No-one sees a way to overcome that shortage, at least not in the immediate future.

The most abiding impression I have was the warmth and the generosity of that welcome and the enthusiasm, the desire, of those women to hear the information we could provide. It would be very sad if the channels of communication opening up from outside to within the Soviet Union were not to continue. I will certainly be looking at ways in which we can continue to stay in contact with those Soviet women and the many more that others of us from this Parliament have had the opportunity to meet, and no doubt other Australians who have been able to journey to the Soviet Union have been able to make friends and acquaintances there. I hope that it does not stop with one parliamentary visit. I think that our delegation, as a group, will want to say that in whatever report we produce. I reiterate: the response from those women was such that it would almost be unmanly behaviour not to provide some way of setting up mechanisms to continue to respond with that sort of information and with access to the goods and services that we in the West enjoy and take for granted. It is very important that we appreciate the benefits we have in this country.

Because of my medical background and interest in health, I was very pleased to have the opportunity to visit a hospital in Leningrad. The best way to describe that is to say that I thought I was in a time warp and had gone back some 40 or 50 years from Australia in the 1990s. I know that some of the health and medical services provided in Russia are world class. Some of its research in health and medicine is world class. But the general provision of services to the broad population would certainly not be acceptable in this country. Again, I hope that there will be imminent changes in the delivery of health care, as there are now discussions about the change in the education system.

All those changes create not only pluses but also a dimension of anxiety. The parents would tell us that their children were asking questions. They are pleased that their children are asking questions, but the parents did not get the chance to ask questions. It is important that the parents also get some kind of education to assist them not only to answer their questions but also to know how to deal with just the right or the opportunity to ask questions-to doubt and to challenge things as well as get more information.

In summary, it was a very rich and rewarding visit. I hope that Australian women and parliamentarians can continue that contact with the Soviet women so that the exchange that we enjoyed can continue and be fruitful for both sides of the Iron Curtain.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.20 p.m.
